question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more of how to figure out answers to technical questions on my own. I learned a great deal about quantum computing, and I have an excellent jumping off point for delving much deeper into this area, something which I had little to none of before the course. I also learned a great deal about quantum computing as a whole.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: For one, the main instructor and TA were both amazing! They were very knowledgeable, and treated us all with the utmost respect. Anytime I had a question in the course, I was always given a direction to go by one of the instructors, and I never felt like it was a silly question or I was wasting their time, as is sometimes the case with instructors. For the size of the class and material covered, I felt like the structure of the course, with 50% interaction, 50% lecture worked excellently. I also 100% love and agree with the style of homework submissions which is no specific due date, and unlimited resubmissions. This style of submission, in my opinion, is the only proper way to do it, as the goal of problem sets should exclusively be to develop understanding of the material. Just to emphasize, I absolutely loved almost every aspect of this course. My background in quantum computing prior to the course was little to none, and I feel like this course did an excellent job at giving me a good base, as well as igniting my excitement for the field overall.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Structure of course is great. The feedbacks on hw is really helpful

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: More teamwork. I think at the beginning of the course, there was an openness to group work, but by mid-end, there was an added emphasis on group work. Attendance policy was great, and the people who came to class wanted to be there. I absolutely approve of this course structure.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The small class made it feel more like a seminar than a large lecture. Questions were often asked by everyone and the professor and TA took the time to make sure that everybody understood the material before moving on. I think this is advantageous since no one is rushing to simply complete problem sets that they don't have a solid understanding of. On a relevant note, I particularly liked that there was no hard due dates for the problem sets. The sets were very long and provided a good introduction to the material where we could think creatively, and we were encouraged to ask detailed questions rather than just completing them. Taking away this pressure really helped me organize my thoughts, take meticulous notes, and set great fundamentals for me to explore quantum computing on my own.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The alternating work days and discussions sections made the course very balanced in terms of lecture material and course work, and the use of a Slack as a way for communication helped faciliate student-instructor interactions. The structure of the course is very good and should be kept as is.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The instructor was very well prepared for lecture, which is possibly the main source of stimulation in a lecture. It's hard to stay engaged if the lecturer is noticeably unprepared, which never occurred in this course. The material was also taught in an overall passionate way and in a way that I could follow and made sense. The only things I would change are to, first of all, slow the pace of lecture just a bit, and two, if able, do a bit more application examples. For reference, I am coming from an EE background, and I felt like the pace of the lecture was just a bit too fast for me. Also, it could be difficult sometimes to imagine what these quantum computers look like physically (how to make, interact, and measure qubits) and how they can be practically used in research, i.e. why they are important.

response_text: It definitely expanded my ideas of linear algebra, allowing me to think about these concepts more abstractly.I would spend a lot of time each week (10-15 hours) working on the homework outside of class and reading the book to understand concepts. However, in the last month the course got very abstract and much harder, and the abstraction made me feel like the course was veering into territory that was less relevant to my research interests. This made me stop submitting homework and then attend lecture far less often, and I then put much more effort into my other classes+interests.I don't know if there would've been a way to prevent me from dropping off in the last month; I don't think it makes sense to water down the content. I just wonder if maybe I wasn't the target audience for this class, and I realized it too late.

response_text: I only selected the above not because I found the course uninteresting or boring, but rather (and understandably so) the course gives an emphasis on the differential geometry aspects of the theory, and there is also some emphasis towards physics (in my opinion), which makes sense, given the crosslisting. However, my background is number theoretic, and while a lot of the theory here is absolutely important for my field, there are a lot of topics that I wished we had touched, even if it was just crumbs (Galois representations, representations over Q and fields of positive characteristic, group cohomology, Lie algebra cohomology, algebraic groups, etc). I know a lot of these are unreasonable for a first course, but I think I would be more than satisfiied if some acknowledgement to these was given. Or perhaps instead of a final exam, a final project or a final presentation would be more stimulating. I know I would feel a lot more excitement if I was writing something about these topics rather than worrying about the exam.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because of the teamwork that we got to do in Friday recitation sections. The material was often presented to us in a convoluted way, and many people left Dr. Wu's lectures feeling more lost than when they came in. Having the chance to work through problems with teammates facilitated an effective learning environment and helped guide people who were lost with the material.This class could be made more stimulating by easing the workload of weekly problem sets, pre-class assignments, and quizzes. Many people in this class have other time-consuming STEM courses that also have weekly homework, and most of the time people in this class felt they could not keep up with the material and assignments. Additionally, the assignments we received were always graded harshly and based on correctness when many people did not know how to do problems because Dr. Wu's lectures were ineffective and confusing. Easing the outside-of-class workload on students and focusing more on team-based, in-person learning would help alleviate stress on students and promote healthy engagement with the material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a lot of work and you have to find the right instructor/TA to explain things. Some of them are condescending when explaining topics and act like everyone should come in knowing a lot of physics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a very thorough course that will give you in-depth knowledge of physics. However, the course moves very rapidly, so having a high school background in physics can be very helpful. The homeworks can be challenging, but there is plenty of help offered in the course, including during helprooms and in the discussion section. If you are taking this course, I would recommend taking other easier courses alongside this one so you have more time to focus on physics. Also, don't procrastinate. Physics builds on itself, and if you get behind, it is extremely hard to catch up. Attend lectures in-person.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course takes a lot of time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's definitely a lot of work with the weekly quizzes, but they are useful so that you're not slammed with studying when the test rolls around. Working on homework with friends was helpful for me, so maybe worth trying out. GPT was solid at getting you started on problems if you were stuck and unable to make it to office hours (not always correct and rarely ever gave you the correct answer to problems).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course, while designed to be a more straightforward physics class, is time-consuming and often will have students feeling lost and confused. Dr. Wu's lectures are often rushed with little in-class help on how to solve problems, which is how you will be graded. While recitation sections are helpful because they allow collaboration and learning from your peers, the material is often handed to you and you are expected to struggle with it. Unfortunately, this version of physics did not achieve what it set out to do, which is to make physics more comprehensible for life sciences students and non-math majors. If you appreciate challenging concepts and independent-learning outside of class, then this one is perfect for you. Otherwise, expect to spend hours a week outside of class on the material, be confused after lecture, and work to perform at the average on assessments and assignments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is well-structured; however, if you studied physics a long time ago, it’s a good idea to review the material beforehand so you don’t feel overwhelmed by the amount of content and the difficulty of the quizzes later. Additionally, the lectures focus heavily on math and deriving formulas, rather than explaining the underlying physics concepts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure that you are putting in time every day, even though it may be hard, it will help you in the long run. I really wish I did that.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be more active throughout the week to keep up with all the work assigned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the physical world, and I developed intuition about physics. I learned how to derive expressions using algebra and calculus, and I learned how to visualize objects moving in space.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: It forced me to think critically about different problems. Other courses (e.g., OChem Biochem, Biology) you understand the material, but you have a lot of practice problems that expose you to pretty much everything that can be asked within reason. However, physics was not like that. While problems were similar, each problem had to be examined on its own, enhancing critical thinking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We took a collaborative approach to the class, which was helpful for team-learning and thinking as a group. Additionally, we learned how to demonstrate problems to the class and talk through our work for certain problems. Finally, we learned how to approach physics problems from the bottom-up to come up with solutions and processes for solving problems.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because of the teamwork that we got to do in Friday recitation sections. The material was often presented to us in a convoluted way, and many people left Dr. Wu's lectures feeling more lost than when they came in. Having the chance to work through problems with teammates facilitated an effective learning environment and helped guide people who were lost with the material.This class could be made more stimulating by easing the workload of weekly problem sets, pre-class assignments, and quizzes. Many people in this class have other time-consuming STEM courses that also have weekly homework, and most of the time people in this class felt they could not keep up with the material and assignments. Additionally, the assignments we received were always graded harshly and based on correctness when many people did not know how to do problems because Dr. Wu's lectures were ineffective and confusing. Easing the outside-of-class workload on students and focusing more on team-based, in-person learning would help alleviate stress on students and promote healthy engagement with the material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a very thorough course that will give you in-depth knowledge of physics. However, the course moves very rapidly, so having a high school background in physics can be very helpful. The homeworks can be challenging, but there is plenty of help offered in the course, including during helprooms and in the discussion section. If you are taking this course, I would recommend taking other easier courses alongside this one so you have more time to focus on physics. Also, don't procrastinate. Physics builds on itself, and if you get behind, it is extremely hard to catch up. Attend lectures in-person.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's definitely a lot of work with the weekly quizzes, but they are useful so that you're not slammed with studying when the test rolls around. Working on homework with friends was helpful for me, so maybe worth trying out. GPT was solid at getting you started on problems if you were stuck and unable to make it to office hours (not always correct and rarely ever gave you the correct answer to problems).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course, while designed to be a more straightforward physics class, is time-consuming and often will have students feeling lost and confused. Dr. Wu's lectures are often rushed with little in-class help on how to solve problems, which is how you will be graded. While recitation sections are helpful because they allow collaboration and learning from your peers, the material is often handed to you and you are expected to struggle with it. Unfortunately, this version of physics did not achieve what it set out to do, which is to make physics more comprehensible for life sciences students and non-math majors. If you appreciate challenging concepts and independent-learning outside of class, then this one is perfect for you. Otherwise, expect to spend hours a week outside of class on the material, be confused after lecture, and work to perform at the average on assessments and assignments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is well-structured; however, if you studied physics a long time ago, it’s a good idea to review the material beforehand so you don’t feel overwhelmed by the amount of content and the difficulty of the quizzes later. Additionally, the lectures focus heavily on math and deriving formulas, rather than explaining the underlying physics concepts.

- discussion TA is super helpful, Bergen was very willing to help and understanding 
- a hard class but manageable if you have the time (try not to overload with it)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is HARD. Be ready to spend most of your time on this course and to do a lot of self-teaching. Lectures are confusing as to what you actually need to know, and it is incredibly high-stress. This class has made me lose my confidence in my abilities and my intelligence.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I'm sorry. Don't take this class with other hard classes. Don't give up and study hard even if it feels hopeless at time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a hard class and even though you do not need to have calculus experience, you are getting the exact same quizzes, exams, and homework sets. So, if you did not want to take 141 because of the stories you've heard, you probably don't want to take this one either.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is basically the same as 141 from what I've heard comparing with previous students.  I think this class is very challenging and even more challenging in concepts compared to any chemistry class I have taken.  This course is not taught like an introductory physics class past the second week, and it will push you to your limits.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is extremely difficult. I did not have any background in physics going into this class and I did not feel like I could catch up from that. It feel like this class was basically 141 and if you do not need to take it for a Duke credit I would take it somewhere else.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Gao was very helpful in answering our questions and spending extra time reviewing topics that we struggled with. I appreciated having time to work in groups before hearing how each group approached their problem.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Gao was always really patient and thorough in explain problems when we had questions. In addition, it was really helpful to have a general overview at the beginning, and then time to work on homework/review problems. I think this structure will also work well for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very helpful and informative about the material that we covered in discussion and was very welcoming. Through at times I was nervous about the quiz at the end of discussion I often anticipated attending my discussion section because I knew I would get better understanding of the material once I talked with her.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that Professor Gao would do a good job of coming from table to table to see what we were struggling with each week, which I found to be extremely helpful, as it allowed us to feel comfortable advocating for ourselves. Additionally, I found the days that Professor Gao would do concept reviews really insightful, as it helped solidify my knowledge on complicated topics such as simple harmonic oscillation. I also thought that the presentations on homework problems was a good chance to test our own conceptual knowledge by presenting what we had come up with on a problem and to learn how to approach difficult problems from other students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We mostly worked in groups to go over the homework problems, which were expected to be mostly complete prior to class, and then put the answers to the problems on the board. This was then followed by taking a short quiz on the week's topics. It was helpful to be able to see other student's work for certain problems if your group did not have time to cover them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved my discussion instructor because she let us ask her lots of questions and tried to help as much as possible. I also enjoyed when she would write on the board for the problems.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The grading structure removed some of the pressure from exams, which made the course less intimidating. I REALLY appreciated the lots of TA office hours that were made available each week (especially the ones in the late evening).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Gao was an excellent teacher who patiently explained all the physics topics we were struggling with in a clear and concise manner. I really liked going over the questions in our small groups and then writing the questions on the board at the end of class. I feel like this gave us the opportunity to explain it to our classmates and in doing so, really learn it ourselves.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Overall, I think being forced to approach difficult Physics problems (i.e. the one on HW 13 with the quadratic formula), show my thinking to my peers and then present on my thinking to the entire class made the class incredibly intellectually stimulating, especially because the looming quiz forced us to develop a strong understanding of the concepts. This was a little bit different from lecture, where the intellectual stimulation often came from learning new topics, but not applying them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the difficulty of the homework made the class stimulating, but I think it would have been more helpful to have more class discussions or TA led lectures to break down concepts further.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think it would be interesting if group quizzes would be implemented.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The labs and demonstrations helped me understand physics concepts and their applications better.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We moved very fast from topic to topic so I had to be engaged to stay on track.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussion section of this course was very helpful. I enjoyed working through problems as a group with my peers. That said, I do wish that students had more time to process the information learned in discussions before being quizzed on it. For example, requiring discussion attendance, and having discussion problem sets that students can work on together that then directly translate into individual homework assignments, then quizzing students makes a lot more sense to me than quizzing students on material before they have submitted their homework for that content.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Doable but not enjoyable

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a lot of work, honestly- but what physics class isn't? Professor Wu is very nice and I would recommend FLUNCHing him, but also you'd better lock in and STUDY for the exams, they're no joke at all. As someone who didn't have any physics experience before entering this course, I would say that it was not very beginner friendly as it had been advertised. There were some weeks when I continually failed the quizzes and didn't understand what I wasn't understanding, if that makes sense. However, I would say that there are tools that they put in place for you to be able to do well in the class. Attend office hours and work with people outside of class to further your understanding! (And pray that he's nice with the grading system because it's looking quite scary right now HAHA.)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a difficult course that will take a lot of work, but if you stay on top of the assignments and show up to lecture, you will generally have a good grasp on the concepts.

response_text: You definitely need to put in a lot of work, but you also get a lot from it.

This was a little bit different from lecture, where the intellectual stimulation often came from learning new topics, but not applying them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussion section of this course was very helpful. I enjoyed working through problems as a group with my peers. That said, I do wish that students had more time to process the information learned in discussions before being quizzed on it. For example, requiring discussion attendance, and having discussion problem sets that students can work on together that then directly translate into individual homework assignments, then quizzing students makes a lot more sense to me than quizzing students on material before they have submitted their homework for that content.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a lot of work, honestly- but what physics class isn't? Professor Wu is very nice and I would recommend FLUNCHing him, but also you'd better lock in and STUDY for the exams, they're no joke at all. As someone who didn't have any physics experience before entering this course, I would say that it was not very beginner friendly as it had been advertised. There were some weeks when I continually failed the quizzes and didn't understand what I wasn't understanding, if that makes sense. However, I would say that there are tools that they put in place for you to be able to do well in the class. Attend office hours and work with people outside of class to further your understanding! (And pray that he's nice with the grading system because it's looking quite scary right now HAHA.)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I'm not sure about during the semester, but for the summer, I don't think the team-based learning worked well. By the second half of the course, the lectures took up most of our time block, so we did not have enough time to do in class problem sets with our team. Also, even if we had time like the last 30 mins of class to do ICP, everyone would do their homework or something else instead because the HW would be due that day and the pacing of the class was super fast. I think this greatly hindered the objectives and effectiveness of team based learning. Therefore, either switching to non-team based learning or coming up with a different schedule/pacing of the course would be necessary. I did like how, by the second half of the course though, that the professor really took the time to explain concepts in lecture by writing them down one by one on paper with us instead of just flipping through the slides that were very confusing to understand by itself. This did take up a lot of time, though, but I think it was helpful to understand the new concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
to be honest, the structure of this course is what hindered my learning the most. I hope the professor realize that 6 hours of class every day is not the best way to teach physics, especially for students who aren't already comfortable with physics. I saw many students, including myself drained out after each class, because we had to digest contents after contents for six hours. 
Also the graders for this class took off way too many points for the most useless stuff.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This has been such a difficult experience. In no world should a summer class be 9am-5pm four days a week. The department states that this style of teaching was designed to accomodate to students and allow RGB to answer questions. In reality, lectures took up 4-4.5 hours every day, leaving limited time for in-class problem sets. The lectures were very long and went into much more detail than what was needed for the exams/quizzes. RGB did spend a lot of time "reviewing" math concepts, however, a lot of the content was tangents filled with unnecessary proofs which we did not need to know. This course is very intense, I sped an average of 14 hours on physics every day, which is not sustainable. I had to quit my job due to the courseload and commitment I have to this course. The homeworks were long and much harder than the quiz problems and exams. The TAs were very helpful. RGB is willing to answer questions after class. I spent little time learning the material and a majority of my time cramming in all of the work by the due date. I would never advise anyone to take this course in the summer, I am sure this class is much more manageable during the semester.

response_text: The learning environment was likely the worst I've had for a class at Duke. response_text: If you have never taken physics, study ahead. Dr. Brown is super funny and nice, but his lectures are hard to follow and were not made for a beginner.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is very difficult, and you cannot expect to simply treat this like an easy course. You will NEED to sit with the content to internalize it in a manner that makes sense to you. But it is not impossible, and the professor and TAs do their best to help you along the way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Use the textbook summaries, they are a great resource and skip over a lot of the in-between stuff that he talks about it class. Go over everything you got wrong and do it again and make sure you can do it without any help. 
This class requires a lot of self-learning, so stay on top of it or you'll be cramming a whole semester into finals week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It seems daunting at first, but it is actually very manageable. Use the mountains of practice resources to your advantage. Develop a strategy for different types of problems so that even if you don't know how to solve something right away, you have a plan of attack. Utilize your teammates and other members of the class. Stay on top of homework assignments-- by staying on top of assignments and quizzes, you don't have to study that much for exams! Use the online textbook on the professor's website-- it is good at explaining concepts when they weren't gone over in lecture in depth.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The in class problem structure of the course helped facilitate my learning. Working in a group on problems was helpful as we could bounce ideas off each other. I would keep this method of instruction for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The TA's were always available which is very helpful. The lectures because easier to digest when the professor switched to solving the problems on paper in front of us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The quizzes helped me not fall behind, and seemed to be an appropriate level of difficulty. Also once RBG starting writing on the board during lecture instead of clicking through slides, I started to learn a bit better.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the amount of practice problems we were provided with, because it made me feel more prepared going into exams. I don't think that the team-based learning was my favorite aspect of the course, because sometimes it felt like we weren't being taught a lot and just were given problems without any idea how to go about them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I'm not sure about during the semester, but for the summer, I don't think the team-based learning worked well. By the second half of the course, the lectures took up most of our time block, so we did not have enough time to do in class problem sets with our team. Also, even if we had time like the last 30 mins of class to do ICP, everyone would do their homework or something else instead because the HW would be due that day and the pacing of the class was super fast. I think this greatly hindered the objectives and effectiveness of team based learning. Therefore, either switching to non-team based learning or coming up with a different schedule/pacing of the course would be necessary. I did like how, by the second half of the course though, that the professor really took the time to explain concepts in lecture by writing them down one by one on paper with us instead of just flipping through the slides that were very confusing to understand by itself. This did take up a lot of time, though, but I think it was helpful to understand the new concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
to be honest, the structure of this course is what hindered my learning the most. I hope the professor realize that 6 hours of class every day is not the best way to teach physics, especially for students who aren't already comfortable with physics. I saw many students, including myself drained out after each class, because we had to digest contents after contents for six hours. 
Also the graders for this class took off way too many points for the most useless stuff.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This has been such a difficult experience. In no world should a summer class be 9am-5pm four days a week. The department states that this style of teaching was designed to accomodate to students and allow RGB to answer questions. In reality, lectures took up 4-4.5 hours every day, leaving limited time for in-class problem sets. The lectures were very long and went into much more detail than what was needed for the exams/quizzes. RGB did spend a lot of time "reviewing" math concepts, however, a lot of the content was tangents filled with unnecessary proofs which we did not need to know. This course is very intense, I sped an average of 14 hours on physics every day, which is not sustainable. I had to quit my job due to the courseload and commitment I have to this course. The homeworks were long and much harder than the quiz problems and exams. The TAs were very helpful. RGB is willing to answer questions after class. I spent little time learning the material and a majority of my time cramming in all of the work by the due date. I would never advise anyone to take this course in the summer, I am sure this class is much more manageable during the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment was likely the worst I've had for a class at Duke. Understandably, this was my first summer class, but the hours of lectures every day on topics that were far too difficult and dense to understand were a horrible 6 weeks of experience. We barely had any time to fully grasp concepts before we were moving onto the next one seconds later. The lectures were hard to follow and monotonous. I also think that because we derived every single formula, I ended up having these notes that were 90% unnecessary and harder to look back at. I understand the purpose, but I'm not sure if it was efficient or effective.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to dedicate or your life to this class. I have not done anything but physics in the past 6 weeks, and I've never felt more stressed. We had an insane amount of work, homework submissions, two quizzes a week, and two labs per week (which each had an in-class portion and an at home portion). The TAs even were struggling with the amount of work they had to grade. I'd say, be prepared to be very overwhelmed and very stressed. They also say you don't need a math background, but you do need a math background and a physics background. I had never taken physics before in my life, and I struggled so much, while to others this was a breeze.  There were way too many different levels of people with different backgrounds walking in, and there was no consideration to that at all. The expectations were the same from everyone. This is very similar to engineering physics, and an equivalent to physics 141/

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

While it is of course good to build your foundations with simpler problems, it could be engaging to include more ties to specific situations students may be interested in applying physics to.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Working in groups and the fact that there are designated moments in class to discuss what we are learning made the course intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was not intellectually stimulating, as the procedural roadblocks we experienced prevented much learning and engagement with the curriculum. Students were assigned a sizable amount of homework each week with little guidance on how to do problems outside of help rooms, which many of us could not attend because we have other classes. As a result, many people felt like they only had time to finish assignments and not truly understand the work required of them. This meant we did not engage much with the material and were at a disadvantage on assessments where we were required to work under time constraints.Additionally, the course's focus on textbook learning instead of practicing hands-on examples made many people seem like we had to teach ourselves and had no guidance from the professor. As a result, many of us acquired a "learned helplessness" such that we felt no amount of work we could do would change our grade or outcome. During discussions with Dr. Wu on how to facilitate effective learning and improvement, many of the class' ideas were refuted or outright discredited as being too easy, and we felt like we actually had no say or control over how the course was taught.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: While this course is meant to be a supplement for those who have not taken calculus before, the class doesn't achieve what it hopes to. It is set up such that you will have to mostly teach yourself, especially if your schedule does not allow you to seek help through help rooms or SAGE (as will probably be the case for most people). The labs are complicated and you receive little guidance from professors and TAs, but you will be graded as if you have an expert understanding of the material. You will have weekly quizzes, pre-class assignments, and problem sets that are not accurately representative of the problems that you are exposed to in class. Not that it particularly matters, because you will have to figure out the steps to solve problems independently of the professor. You will have opportunities for some extra credit, but these will likely not compensate for performance on assessments. Expect to mostly teach yourself and to struggle with the concepts throughout the semester. Otherwise, you would be better off taking physics elsewhere.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Do NOT take this class if you do not have calculus experience. They are supposed to teach us the calculus with this version of the course, but trust and believe that they do not. This class is literally just 141 rebranded but not changed.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared for a rigorous course that will occupy a majority of your study time. Although it is advertised as a new revamp of 141, it is not much easier or revamped. Often the exams were harder than the ones from 141. I would take this course during a lighter semester because it is incredibly time consuming and challenging.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Go to help desk hours and be ready to put in a lot of time for the homework problems.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class requires a lot of intrinsic motivation and effort outside of lecture to truly understand the concepts. Going to office hours is helpful, especially if your team is less prepared or participatory during discussion.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Stay on top of the content!!!! Go to office hours!!!!!! Office hours is the best place to learn

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don’t take it during a busy semester. You’ll need to dedicate 8-10 hours outside of the course to physics in order to do well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You need to know that if you join this class, your gpa will suffer. If you're coming into this class with no math experience, you're not going to get any actual calculus learning done in here and I feel it would be impossible for you to succeed. If you've never had a physics class before either, I wouldn't even bother taking this. You have to come into this with some prior knowledge because you're going to be teaching yourself most things anyways.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a difficult course and I would not take it with a bunch of other difficult classes because it takes time and effort. Going to lecture is important because the notes don't always show everything.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you keep up with it and do most (if not all) of the practice problems provided it becomes much easier to do well in the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: do the homeworks before the quizzes, and the practice exams before the actual exams.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I can't say I recommend it; but at the same time, there is really no good alternative. Take it, but realize that this class is going to be incredibly time consuming, between preclass assignments, homeworks, studying for quizzes, and otherwise teaching yourself, it should not be taken in conjunction with other intensive courses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don’t take it here unless you have a relatively strong physics background (taken AP in the last year or a college level physics course). It’s really difficult and not worth it. People are not exaggerating when they say that. Prof. Wiu is lovely but the class is not structured for beginners.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't take it unless you absolutely need to or feel confident in your ability to do well in the course. The content is time-consuming and challenging, which is good if you want a thorough understanding of physics. If you simply need a physics credit for your major and aren't concerned with a deep learning of the content, then it may be best to take the class somewhere else. It is not a bad course, it simply isn't catered to the needs of all students and is difficult to manage with other commitments, especially if you want to do well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would like to say that it is difficult and to not get too behind on course content. Make sure to utilize class resources and office hours.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that the instructor was excellent and did a really nice job facilitating the transition from physics 141 to physics 121. He tried so hard to make the experience great for students and most of all he listened to each and every student's feedback. He was receptive and I don't think you could ask for more from a professor. I thought that the course allowed for multiple ways to do well and even if you got one bad quiz score or lab score you were able to drop it and that was really relieving to know your entire grade wasn't based on one assessment. It was nice to have many opportunities to do well and show all of the effort you have put in. I really liked how the grading was broken down in this course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the discussion sections where we went over the homework and did weekly quizzes. While the quizzes were a bit annoying to do, they kept me responsible for the content that I needed to learn each week. I also really liked Dr. Wu's style of teaching, where we did practice in lectures. Moreover, the math labs and math along the way were very useful and also took some stress away from submitting more assignments.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He failed to explain topics, leaving students confused. Students did most of their learning online. YouTube was my best friend.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor wanted to focus on team based learning but the table I was assigned to never had more than 3 people and never talked so it wasn't that effective. Then the professor would want us to do the questions and barely gives us time to do it and when he explains the work he explains super quickly. Half the time he also writes the solution using the laser feature on goodnotes so the solution disappears in 5 seconds without us even being able to understand how to solve the problem. I think the team based groups would be nice if they could be reshuffled halfway through the semester. Honestly the assigned groups were never used in my lab or discussion so I don't think there is any point in going through the trouble of ensuring the people in the groups for lecture are also in the same discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The language of the course can be open towards learning. A lot of the teachers/TA's will say "its easy" or get quickly frustrated with students when the don't immediately understand a topic which makes it hard for students to learn because they feel pressured to get the concept as soon as its taught or they will be judged. The way topics are explained could be better as well. The teacher will go on tangents about how to derive an equation (when the process of deriving it is not important to the concept, or he has stated that it doesn't need to be known) but doesn't show when students need to start knowing the content leaving it up to students throughout the week to devise which equations and topics, we actually need for the course. If he could establish the concepts more concretely in class that would be great. We only go through concepts (extremely quick without the actually reasoning behind the concept being explained rendering the exercise quick useless) once a week but are expected to know all of the concepts and reasoning behind a topic when it is not lectured nor shown to us.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a lot of work, from the weekly quizzes, hw, pre-class assignments, and labs, there is a lot to stay on top of. However, Dr. Wu is very approachable and very kind. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The homework is much harder than the lecture. I also did not like how much time was wasted in lectures instead of doing practice problems. We would often end early. Even now it is the last lecture before exam 3 and we have not done any physics work and its 12:30. I would appreciate if the class did more problems and the concepts were explained through practice problems. Also it would be helpful if the demonstrations were explained more. For buoyancy examples, they would show us something and then that would be it. Explaining the concept live by perhaps writing on the board would be helpful. Overall, this course was one of my least favorite at Duke due to the strong disconnect between lectures and the homework. I feel like topics were given to us but they were never explained clearly. Also the concept questions did not have detailed solutions which made checking work and learning unnecessarily difficult.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

response_text: It was extremely frustrating to feel like I was doing everything I could and still nearly failing. I went to help room essentially every week, sometimes for two or three hours. I attended one-on-one tutoring sessions again and again. I went to SAGE. I met with my lab partners outside of class. I spent about 15 hours a week on this one course--which is absurd when you consider that an average course load of 4 courses would necessitate 60 hours of work per week if they all required that much time. There were times in SAGE or tutoring sessions when I found physics genuinely interesting, but in the actual class I was so lost and frustrated that I could not possibly find it enjoyable (except occasionally lab).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will learn everything yourself. The lecture is just to go over 1-2 topics from the assigned readings and solve 1-2 problems. The concept quizzes will still cover stuff from the readings, even if they were not covered in lecture. It is a hard class, but I do think the topics in physics 2 are more interesting than in physics 1. Definitely still need to do math. It will definitely be hard, and it will challenge you constantly. Even if you did the practice problems, the midterm will still be hard and mix up different skills, I'd say. You definitely need to understand the why of physics. Concept-heavy, I'd say. A LOT of formulas to learn. He says it should be intuitive if you understand the why, but honestly, with the time you have to learn all these topics, you definitely have to memorize because it is so hard to learn in depth everything to derive formulas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures every day were good reviews of the material that we learned in the textbook. The instructor was engaging and passionate about the subject, and he was always eager to answer our questions during class and to make time to help students understand topics outside of class. I would keep the flipped learning style where we read the textbook outside of class and review the content inside of class -- I think it was helpful to be able to take my time in learning the concepts on my own outside of class before the lecture, instead of having to learn it quickly during lecture. I also think that the lecture videos were very helpful because I was able to pause and rewind these videos until I understood a concept I was struggling with.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I enjoyed the collaborative work and for other students to explain their thoughts and work on a problem. I sometimes think physics TAs and professors will overcomplicate or overexplain or even talk as if we understand everything they say right in that moment, and students, on the other hand, explain stuff easier and in ways we can actually understand. We can talk to each other in simple terms and in a language that we can understand. I enjoyed having Tyler as a TA, don't get me wrong. He does his best to explain and helps you when other students don't. But I enjoyed that discussion, has no pressure of having the practice problems graded, because it definitely becomes a matter of understanding without being punished for a mistake when we are barely learning.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say to keep up every day with the textbook readings and always do the discussion problems -- doing these two things will help greatly on the daily concept quizzes and the bi-weekly discussion quiz. I would also say to be persistent and rigorous in approaching each question, meaning that even if it seems complicated and difficult in the beginning, have confidence and keep at it -- you will be able to solve the problem.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very hard class, but doable.

response_text: Prepare for as many discussion questions as you can before coming to class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: My one qualm is the grading - admittedly, I am still unsure how my grade will turn out - but I don't feel hopeful, because a minimum of 40% of my grade rides on my final, and based on my performance on the one midterm, I do not have faith in my ability to do well. I think this is largely in part because the exams for this class ask incredibly difficult concept questions and are graded such that it is easy to lose a large amount of points very quickly (by nature of being out of small point values, like 20 points). This is a frusrating feeling, because I, like other students, have worked incredibly hard to succeed in this class, and likely harder than I would've worked had I taken this class during a normal fall/spring semester. What feels unfair is that I might end up with a low grade due to the unforgiving nature of the difficult exams, when I feel strongly that had I taken the class at a different time/with a different professor, I think I would've almost certainly be ending with an A.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to think about sports through a physics lens, and how to formulate sports phenomena as physics problems
2. I learned about the laws of physics and how they apply to sports
3. I learned how physics and statistics influence the strategy of sports and why games are played certain ways.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a few things in this class that I never learned in prior physics classes. The first was angular motion, which involved solving for multidimensional velocities. We also learned about Torque, which can work clockwise as a negative number, or counterclockwise as a positive number. Finally, we also learned about Magnus force, which is the force acting on a ball when it is spinning a certain way in the air. This helped us look at baseballs and basketballs and how they travel through the air.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the kinematics of many sports, as in projectiles flying through the air. I learned about forces, how to calculate the force on an object in a variety of scenarios. I learned about energy as well, converting between different types and how the body uses energy in different sports.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I mainly developed methods of thinking of the world in terms of physics, specifically in sports. I learned about the angular velocity in a baseball when it is initially pitched, the relationship that exists between density and altitude, and about the physics behind pole-vaulting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered a lot of physics mechanics, the type of things that you'd generally encounter in an AP physics class. We went a little further than that though, learning about things like buoyancy and magnus force which don't really come up in beginner physics classes. The entire course was delivered through the scope of sports, which was a nice way of learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The slides used were poorly organized and designed and often had spelling, grammatical, and mathematical errors. The actual presentation of the slides was unengaging, often consisting of the instructor simply reading almost word-for-word off of the slides. The lectures were clearly on the fly with no preparation done beforehand, evidenced by the fact that the instructor infrequently knew what he was going to teach about next.
The homeworks were assigned on an clunky online platform. This platform only took into account final answers, meaning details as minute as rounding errors could cause the answer to be completely wrong. In order to redo the incorrect problems to get points back, the platform required that you do the whole problem set again (with different numbers), including the answers you already got correct. In addition, other parts of the homework, like the coding portions, were often vaguely described leaving the student doing lots of guesswork as to what the assignment was.
Rubrics for projects were extremely vague and were, as it turned out, not actually meant to be followed. 
Overall, it was a poorly designed class that had more tedious and arbitrary work than thoughtful, stimulating work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed how there were multiple discussion sections per week, because I was NOT going to understand the content of a whole lecture the first time around. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was very difficult. It is an intense physics class. Every homework felt like it was in a foreign language because the content was so vast and so advanced. However, Ronen as a professor is very good. He is open to any suggestions and really just wants everyone to succeed. If you are interested in this topic and are willing to put in a lot of effort to understand it then its a good course. I went to office hours every week to ask questions and Ronen is very helpful and supportive and good at explaining things if you know exactly what you're asking. Also, the observations are very fun and interesting and a good way to connect to the material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: At times the work is difficult, but the workload is extremely manageable. If you are not interested in astronomy and physics then do not take this class you will probably not like it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Not for the faint of heart! If it has been a while since you've done any sort of math or physics (like me), or if you feel unsure about your skills in that area, the homework and exams will probably be difficult. Ronen is super helpful with homework as long as you are willing to put in the extra effort and go to office hours or the discussion. For an introductory course, this is pretty hard, but interesting nonetheless.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do not take this class if you are not good at physics and/or do not need this credit. Take if you are good at or enjoy physics and have the extra time to put in the work. Difficult course if you do not know what you are doing. Lots of material and moves fast. Prof is obviously very passionate about what he teaches and is always willing to help his students. One of the kindest professors I met and he is definitely my favorite, but his class is just difficult for me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't take it if you just want to learn about astronomy or think it will be an interesting way to fulfill a requirement it was very difficult for someone who is not a math/science-minded person. Ronen is a great person but often it's confusing to figure out what he wants and how to do the homework without his help.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Listen to me: take this class. Yes it's hard and yes it might hurt your GPA and yes it gets cold and miserable when you go out for observations in December when it's cold and wet. But for a lot of classes, they end after the semester. You forget them in a year or two; it just happens that way, because you can't possibly remember everything. This class isn't like that. You will not forget this class for as long as you live, because it's everywhere. You can see it in the sun and sky above you, the earth and sea below you, and all the weird, wonderful things humanity has placed all around you through breakthrough after breakthrough in science and cooperation. Trust the anonymous reviewer. Don't let fear of a bad grade or wet shoes or anything else stand in your way. Take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do not take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class has been labeled as easier in the past, but with this professor, I would not call it easy. The professor is great, takes feedback, answers questions, and wants everyone to do their best, but the material and the homework/exams are very difficult sometimes. If you've never taken physics or aren't a physics-minded person, it can take a lot of hours of work to understand. But also, if you're curious about how the universe works or want exposure to physics without the calculus or taking normal physics classes, this course is great. Also, the observations are so, so cool! You get to learn how to use telescopes and observe individual stars, star clusters, binary stars, galaxies, planets, and the moon. That part was definitely worth it!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the structure of the course worked really well for the level that most students were expected to be at in the beginning of the course. Professor Scolnic guided us through the concepts well, and I think that in-class homework checks were a fair way to make sure we were paying attention and that we were doing the readings. I also liked them because we were able to immediately correct ourselves with the class if we got the question wrong, so I thought it was a good form of active learning. I also enjoyed hearing about Professor Scolnic's experiences working as an astronomer, even if they weren't the most relevant to the class material. It's not every day you meet someone who works in astronomy, so it was really interesting to hear what that kind of work was like. He was also very receptive to hearing our questions, and I honestly appreciated that he also didn't know everything and was confused about some of the concepts himself. It made me feel a lot better about my own learning.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class starts off intimidating. It claims to be ideal for people without a Physics background, but the whole first half is a recap (with quizzes and a midterm) of Physics 1. The quizzes and midterm are just reskins of the homework problems, so they are not too hard. The assignments and content are actually really cool if you care about the subject at all. The writing assignments are long, but you do get a W credit and they are graded quite leniently.

response_text: Physics is hard. There's no other way to say it. But as long as you do your best to complete all the work and go to help room for homework and other questions, it is manageable. Going to help room and being able to ask one on one questions is also really helpful because you're able to work through your questions step by step. Discussion is also helpful because you're also able to get step by step guidance, but whichever TA you get will determine how helpful discussion is for you.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is meant to be teamed based, so by working together through problems we could better help each other understand the complex topics we were learning. He also has a large number of problems we could work both in and out of class which was helpful for practicing. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Dr. Brown reads off of slides and goes through problems very quickly. I rarely knew where he was getting different values from. We had class for four hours twice a week because the lecture section was followed by discussion or lab. We took quizzes at the end of the period on Wednesdays on the material we learned the week before. So we had already "learned" next week's material before we even took the quiz for the prior week. This schedule made it incredibly difficult to learn. I would much rather focus on one topic at a time than try to learn new information for three hours and then take a quiz on material from over a week ago.
