question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Summer classes tend to favor those who have previous experience (e.g. those who took the AP class but not the exam; international students from outside of the Duke-recognized education systems and need the credits). If you identify with that, this class will be perfect for you. You can do very little work and get really good grades. However, if you're starting physics from scratch, don't take this class unless you're 100% motivated. Else, it will feel like the entire system is designed against you, which in some sense is quite true.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Instructor, Prof. Roy, was extremely knowledgeable on the subject of Physics, this allowed for his instruction to be clear, coherent, and proactive. This allowed me to learn in a very effective manner through the summer 6-week course. He used weekly quizzes, homeworks, discussion, and labs to make sure his students are on track with their learning. I believe all four should definitely kept for future years. In addition, I found the experiments done in class to be in fact very helpful, as a visual learner it helped me put what we learned in lecture into a visual/real life problem. In addition, going over practice problems and developing an algorithm to complete certain homework problems was extremely helpful. In physics sometimes it feels as if there are several equations and routes one can go to solve a problem. Roy, had an algorithm his students should follow, and it greatly helped me.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Arya Roy is one of the best professors that I've had at Duke! He is an engaging lecturer and made me quite interested in and curious about physics. I appreciate Dr. Roy's excitement for talking about all things physics outside of class. I really enjoyed the demonstrations that Derek did for us too. The post-lecture notes were often helpful, and I appreciated the alternating structure of discussion and lab and the daily homework sets.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be honest with yourself and your knowledge of physics. If you genuinely have excellent preparation, a summer class is perfect. If you haven't, a summer class may be a challenge due to the fact that it is accelerated. Many students have excellent preparation so the course content comes easily to them. If you need more time to understand difficult concepts, this class will be a challenge. You can definitely do it, you might jus not get an A (and that's okay) and you might be very stressed. The summer class itself isn't that bad if you have realistic expectations.

response_text: It is definitely a difficult course but Dr. Roy does his best to explain things well. Having a strong foundation in physics helps greatly but you also need to spend time outside of class working out problems yourself to understand the concepts. Dr. Roy is incredibly nice and brings a positive attitude to class. It's better to go into class having read the notes on that topic before class because it can be easy to get a little bit lost during lecture because not everything is laid out in the most introductory friendly way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to work and put in your best effort into the course! it is not easy, but Roy is a great professor willing to teach and help his students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're taking Physics 141 during the summer, take advantage of talking to Dr. Roy outside of class! Also, take advantage of having the time to use resources like office hours and SAGE. The course is quite fast-paced during the summer, and it may feel overwhelming at first, but you will get used to the pace. Make yourself accountable for doing homework problems every day because it's easy to fall behind. Refrain from committing to responsibilities outside of physics because you'll spend a lot of time in class/lab/discussion and will want time to focus on HW. However, I worked in a lab around 10 hrs/week, which was still manageable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a huge commitment but worth it if your goal is to really understand physics and end with a good grade.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is definitely hard, and taking accelerated t over the summer makes it a major and stressful time commitment-- particularly in Professor Brown's section of the class. You quite literally do not have time to do anything else (6 hours of physics coursework a day plus homework and studying). You can do well, but you cannot fall behind without truly feeling the consequences and becoming lost. Professor Brown is very understanding and helpful though, and wants everyone to do well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is very time consuming, but if you can spend time on it you can really understand it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of time commitment with this course, especially if you take a little longer to grasp the concepts. The workload is heavy, but as long as you have good time management skills, you'll be fine. Also, don't be afraid to ask for clarification. Physics can be difficult and you don't want to be lost throughout the whole course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's an extremely difficult course if you have zero physics background. The hours are awful, and you'll honestly be working on physics 24/7. Do not take this with another class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Taking physics in the summer is time-consuming, but extremely rewarding. Dr. Brown is great at providing as many practice problems as possible in order to ensure you master topics. The emphasis on team-building and a lack of competition promotes an encouraging environment in which everyone feels they can succeed. Although there is a decent amount of homework, it ultimately is beneficial to your performance.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is intense, be prepared

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course requires effort and concentration, but is definitely set up so that students are able to master the content and succeed. Time management is a big part of it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A great professor clearly passionate about his subject, but a rigorous course you must be prepared to tackle.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Robert Brown is an excellent and brilliant professor and I have greatly enjoyed learning from him. Taking it during the summer is difficult because there is a lot of material to cover in a short amount of time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're able to take it somewhere else or during a regular semester, do so. Summer term physics 141 (Brown and Mckenzie) is not sustainable and is extremely difficult to keep up with. This course meets 6 hours a day with 10+ hours spend after class daily, meaning continued nights of little to no sleep. Physics background in high school will not help you, even 6 years is not helpful. If you have no physics background, it will be like learning an extremely difficult STEM class in a completely foreign language with no time to adjust. This is a class to take if you are majoring in Physics or doing something with Physics in your future, not something to take in order to get your major requirement or prepare for the MCAT.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: be ready to invest about 20-30+ hours outside of the class a week to keep up if it is done over the summer. stay on top of the work do not fall behind!!

response_text: I would brush up on calculus skills before taking this course. Also be prepared for a lot of time outside of the class spent working on assignments and studying.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're able to take it somewhere else or during a regular semester, do so. Summer term physics 141 (Brown and Mckenzie) is not sustainable and is extremely difficult to keep up with. This course meets 6 hours a day with 10+ hours spend after class daily, meaning continued nights of little to no sleep. Physics background in high school will not help you, even 6 years is not helpful. If you have no physics background, it will be like learning an extremely difficult STEM class in a completely foreign language with no time to adjust. This is a class to take if you are majoring in Physics or doing something with Physics in your future, not something to take in order to get your major requirement or prepare for the MCAT.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is the first class in a while that I learned something. As a premed (chem major), professors here at Duke make you memorize random factoids and expect you to regurgitate them exactly as they lectured. Wu was one of the only professors I had to care about his students learning. I bet if you give me a torque balance, fluids, or waves problem 5 years from now, the chances of me knowing my way around it is about 10 times greater than anything I have learned in a biology class at Duke (keep in mind they are preparing pre-med students who need to know all of biology!). The class is hard? Yes. What else do you expect from a physics course at Duke. Quizzes are fair. Exams are fair. Tons of office hours. TAs are great (this doesn't happen in any other STEM classes at Duke). Wu is a legend and the Physics Dept should be very thankful of having him.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many physics concepts that I had not known before. We covered waves, circular motion, kinematics, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problem-solving, basic calculus as applied to physics formulas, critical thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze systems and determine what forces are acting upon them. I learned how to do mathematical analysis and manipulation to find the values of unknown variables. Finally, I learned about new concepts such as kinetic and static friction, torque, moment of inertia, conservation of mechanical energy, conservation of momentum, work-kinetic energy theorem, longitudinal and transverse waves, and standing waves. I also learned how to find out whether beats can be detected by humans as well as the Doppler effect.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach physics from the perspectives of kinematics, forces, fluids, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned that I love physics! I was worried about this class because it is rated as difficult but I found myself loving the content which, in turn, made it easier for me to study and learn. Applied math is so fun.
2) I learned a lot about waves. This topic was challenging for me in high school as well as in the beginning of learning it this semester. However, the homework and additional problems helped me to finally understand a topic I had struggled with previously.
3) I learned a new way of thinking about the world. Viewing the world via a physics lens is so entertaining. Every ball that falls, or plane that takes off, or movie about space has a relationship to what was learned in class. I found my mind constantly making real-world connections to content learned in lecture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is so hard and it's a constant uphill battle. You have hard HW due every week. You have quizzes EVERY week, even on exam weeks. You can never get a break from studying. While this forces you to not procrastinate, it is overwhelming at times. I don't know how I would've survived if I hadn't taken physics in high school. If you take this class and have no physics background, learn some physics beforehand or else you're going to have a very very hard time. You do learn SO MUCH but I don't know if it's worth the time and effort. Fortunately, Dr. Wu is a kind man and does give extra credit and opportunities for grade boosts. He says that he "tries to make the class not stressful," which is ...questionable, but I suppose the grade leniency is his way of reducing stress.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like that, for an introductory course, Professor Roy posted the solutions to the questions with the homework problems. I know one of the concerns with doing this was that students would just memorize the solutions and not really gain an understanding of how to work the problems. However, I really tried my best to work of the HW problem by myself and use the solutions as a push (and source of understanding) when I got stuck, which was many many times. Having the solutions was really helpful because for myself personally, I don't get an eureka moment when I'm stuck, and I get frustrated. But, having the solutions readily available relieved some of the frustration, and allowed me to move on.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely think this course helped me learn quick acquisition of skills and especially pattern recognition. Due to the high workload, sometimes there wasn't enough time for total comprehension of a unit so learning to recognize patterns in examples was a very good skill I learned in completing this course. I think the method at which I learned material was also very different because of the pace of the course. I had to spend a lot more time actually sitting down and reading about the math rather than just performing calculations and connecting the new topics to what we had previously learned was a useful skill that made the number of equations easier to handle.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class made me question life entirely and where we came from. I learned how to put the concepts I learned in physics 141 to use, although in an unexpected manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify different types of circuits and the currents and voltages that are produced within them. - I remembered my love of math and mathematical-based proofs

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The group-based learning is excellent, and I cannot stress this enough. There is a wonderful amount of material available for preparation for quizzes/tests; I find the ICPs very helpful and the problems of the homework that involve deriving and recapitulating core concepts, as well as the concept review itself. The ways in which homework is harder than quizzes, which are somewhat harder than tests (to me, so far), is a good way to help us clear hurdles in this tricky subject without destroying our grades. Dr. Brown is very passionate and knowledgeable, the information tested is very fair, and it is quite clear what is expected of us. I can't speak yet to the final; many classes I've been in have made the final decently harder than midterms, which somewhat defeats the purpose of grade replacement, but so far the midterms at least have felt very reasonable (maybe almost too reasonable, seeing how much of this second midterm we just took seems to have been lifted directly from practice problems).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The content was superbly stimulating. The instruction, however, was most definitely not. RGB literally ONLY reads off his slides; I'm about as mathematically inclined as they come in intro physics and even to me it sounded like just pure mathematical gibberish. He means well and is really nice, but god forbid should you ask him a question because that's an easy way to waste two hours of your life away. He will do anything but give a straightforward answer, instead choosing to aimlessly meander among a series of unrelated topics in math and philosophy. He's an incredibly interesting person and, once again, definitely seems to mean well but he sorely needs to be taught a lesson or two in getting to the point. Might be one of the truly rare instances of someone being too smart to teach. Also want to add, his textbook is really thorough but I was unable to understand a lot of it without consulting other texts in conjunction because, while verbose, the book doesn't lay a very good foundation in terms of intuition/derivations for several of the topics.
As for Ken, he's a nice enough person but something about him telling our lab TA to grade our labs harsher and forbidding him from giving us 20/20s on labs rubbed me the wrong way. Physics II isn't a cakewalk as it is, labs are certainly NOT the place to penalize us even more, especially those completed with thought and effort. Labs are super cool though and definitely enhance our physical understanding; could be better designed though, they seem a bit out of touch sometimes and might need more modernization.

response_text: I found the content of this course intellectually stimulating, but the way it was taught impeded my ability to acquire said content. His lectures were premade and is the same curriculum used for 162 students. He lectured us in a manner assuming that the conceptual ideas came naturally to us, which made me feel inadequate. I think spending more time explaining the concepts of what we are learning rather than the math would be more beneficial for my retention. I found myself using YouTube a lot more because it was more helpful than his lectures. By the end of the course, half the class stopped attending lectures since we basically learned the entire course by ourselves. I was too afraid to ask the professor for help because he made me feel dumb for not knowing content.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
1. Print out textbook sections before class or use a tablet to take notes on the page. His slides and textbook sections cover almost the same things in the same order and copying everything from the slides onto a blank sheet of paper is exhausting and you will not survive the 3-hour lectures. Save yourself mental capacity by highlighting and annotating the textbook. I learned this too late. 
2. Find a study partner. Someone you are able to share vulnerability with, because in this class you will constantly feel inferior and not enough (at least I did). Knowing that others are feeling the same way really helps. 
3. There are 13 problem sets and I personally spent 12+ hours on each (excluding a few towards the end of the course). I was working every weekend from morning to midnight just like school days and currently I seem to be getting a B at best so I probably invested my time on the wrong things. This is my first physics class since 7th grade; if you are new like me, do not believe in people who say "RGB gives 2/3 of his class A or A+" because you will not be one of them. That's OK. Grow at your own pace. You are amazing in your own way. 
4. Office hours do not exist. You have minimal help available. Do not worry about whether the professor will judge you etc.; ask questions whenever you can. 
5. MATH 212/222 (multivariable calculus) helps a lot. 
6. Personally disliked how he refers to students he had since 141 as "my students" when discussing relevant 141 material. [e.g. "My students derived this equation for homework; I don't know whether your professors did the same."] Like what do you mean, we are all your students. Would really appreciate if he doesn't comment on things like that, or change into something like "derive this equation in your spare time if you haven't already." 
7. Randomly cancels class, especially on afternoons, at the cost of rushing through things in the morning. I tried speaking out when he "takes a poll" on students' opinion of lecture pace but I seem to be the minority.
8. Labs were fun and manageable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you love physics, take it with RGB; if you don't, take it with literally anyone else or you will hate yourself. Not a knock on RGB at all, but his infectious love for physics enhances the experience for those who share that passion too, but can make the class much more difficult and less straightforward for those who are not so inclined. Either way, be prepared for a ton of fun because this class, if you allow it to and really immerse yourself in it, will change your life and how you perceive the universe. A bold statement, I know, but it's true; physics has changed my thought process about *everything* in a way I didn't even conceive was possible. Put in the work and you will definitely be rewarded, not necessarily with grades but definitely with satisfaction and knowledge. Let yourself enjoy physics!!! It's totally worth it.

The ways in which homework is harder than quizzes, which are somewhat harder than tests (to me, so far), is a good way to help us clear hurdles in this tricky subject without destroying our grades. Dr. Brown is very passionate and knowledgeable, the information tested is very fair, and it is quite clear what is expected of us. I can't speak yet to the final; many classes I've been in have made the final decently harder than midterms, which somewhat defeats the purpose of grade replacement, but so far the midterms at least have felt very reasonable (maybe almost too reasonable, seeing how much of this second midterm we just took seems to have been lifted directly from practice problems).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The content was superbly stimulating. The instruction, however, was most definitely not. RGB literally ONLY reads off his slides; I'm about as mathematically inclined as they come in intro physics and even to me it sounded like just pure mathematical gibberish. He means well and is really nice, but god forbid should you ask him a question because that's an easy way to waste two hours of your life away. He will do anything but give a straightforward answer, instead choosing to aimlessly meander among a series of unrelated topics in math and philosophy. He's an incredibly interesting person and, once again, definitely seems to mean well but he sorely needs to be taught a lesson or two in getting to the point. Might be one of the truly rare instances of someone being too smart to teach. Also want to add, his textbook is really thorough but I was unable to understand a lot of it without consulting other texts in conjunction because, while verbose, the book doesn't lay a very good foundation in terms of intuition/derivations for several of the topics.
As for Ken, he's a nice enough person but something about him telling our lab TA to grade our labs harsher and forbidding him from giving us 20/20s on labs rubbed me the wrong way. Physics II isn't a cakewalk as it is, labs are certainly NOT the place to penalize us even more, especially those completed with thought and effort. Labs are super cool though and definitely enhance our physical understanding; could be better designed though, they seem a bit out of touch sometimes and might need more modernization.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is much, much, more challenging than physics 141. For an easier time, I would have taken a semester's class on multivariable calculus before doing this one.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
1. Print out textbook sections before class or use a tablet to take notes on the page. His slides and textbook sections cover almost the same things in the same order and copying everything from the slides onto a blank sheet of paper is exhausting and you will not survive the 3-hour lectures. Save yourself mental capacity by highlighting and annotating the textbook. I learned this too late. 
2. Find a study partner. Someone you are able to share vulnerability with, because in this class you will constantly feel inferior and not enough (at least I did). Knowing that others are feeling the same way really helps. 
3. There are 13 problem sets and I personally spent 12+ hours on each (excluding a few towards the end of the course). I was working every weekend from morning to midnight just like school days and currently I seem to be getting a B at best so I probably invested my time on the wrong things. This is my first physics class since 7th grade; if you are new like me, do not believe in people who say "RGB gives 2/3 of his class A or A+" because you will not be one of them. That's OK. Grow at your own pace. You are amazing in your own way. 
4. Office hours do not exist. You have minimal help available. Do not worry about whether the professor will judge you etc.; ask questions whenever you can. 
5. MATH 212/222 (multivariable calculus) helps a lot. 
6. Personally disliked how he refers to students he had since 141 as "my students" when discussing relevant 141 material. [e.g. "My students derived this equation for homework; I don't know whether your professors did the same."] Like what do you mean, we are all your students. Would really appreciate if he doesn't comment on things like that, or change into something like "derive this equation in your spare time if you haven't already." 
7. Randomly cancels class, especially on afternoons, at the cost of rushing through things in the morning. I tried speaking out when he "takes a poll" on students' opinion of lecture pace but I seem to be the minority.
8. Labs were fun and manageable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you love physics, take it with RGB; if you don't, take it with literally anyone else or you will hate yourself. Not a knock on RGB at all, but his infectious love for physics enhances the experience for those who share that passion too, but can make the class much more difficult and less straightforward for those who are not so inclined. Either way, be prepared for a ton of fun because this class, if you allow it to and really immerse yourself in it, will change your life and how you perceive the universe. A bold statement, I know, but it's true; physics has changed my thought process about *everything* in a way I didn't even conceive was possible. Put in the work and you will definitely be rewarded, not necessarily with grades but definitely with satisfaction and knowledge. Let yourself enjoy physics!!! It's totally worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it with Dr. Brown! He is passionate/cares about his students, knows the material impressively well, and tries to teach the material in a way that leaves no steps out, makes a lot of sense, is directly relevant to things we care about (solar panels, MRI, various important devices that rely on magnetism and electricity come to mind), and doesn't patronize us by dumbing things down significantly to the point where the class becomes "memorize this formula, trust me it works" like other physics classes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very involved and requires a lot of outside work to make sure your conceptual understanding is on par to move on in the course. If you do put in the work, the assessments are fair and straightforward, and Dr. Brown is a lenient professor as well

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Brown was an amazing instructor and facilitated my learning by talking about the application of physics concepts. It is very intriguing and definitely makes me want to learn more. I think the reason his teaching was very good is because he would project his work onto the board and sometimes use the slides.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked lecture and then doing the problems. For more information-packed lectures, though, it was super super hard to keep up. Students wouldn't ask questions because many were confused as the topic matter went right over their heads. I think shortening the 3 hour lecture to 1.5 may be better. Maybe lecture for 45 and then problems for the rest? I also liked that RGB was very friendly. He was very nice and even brought cheesecakes to class once. I also preferred when RGB wrote the lecture on paper. After trying out both hand written notes and powerpoints, hand-written notes wins. I was less likely to pay attention if the lecture was on powerpoint. I felt like RGB structures them better on paper.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The layering of lecture and problem solving was extremely helpful for helping students retain and practice information learned.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class is physics, and physics is hard. It was challenging and I learned so much! But I never want to do it again!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was definitely stimulating, the topics covered were quite honestly fascinating, but some of the topics were not relevant to us (ex. Phasor diagrams, which are more relevant to an engineering class). Focusing on topics more relevant to us may have made the course more engaging, although I think in general Dr. Brown did a good job of this.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The help room sessions as well as team based learning with our classmates.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: very hard Course. make sure to understand the material, and make time to practice problems.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will not have time for anything if you take physics 2 over the summer. Make sure to do the in-class problems set during the time he gives you and ask questions. I felt very burnt out by the end of the lecture, but I stuck it out! I regret not doing them when he was there.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I believe that with RGB it is worth it to get physics over with in the summer. When I took it summer term 1 for 141 I had my doubts, but even with the crazy schedule, I feel I enjoyed myself more and retained more information in 142. RGB is also a nice person. If you were to take this class, I'd recommend working on the homeworks during the week so you have the weekend to study the topics you just learned. I'd recommend mastering every problem you see and every resource RGB gives you. Every. Resource. Study for the quizzes 2-3 days in advance. 3 max. Put in the work every week so you do not stress during the exam season. You got this, you can do it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Physics 2 is hard, no matter who is teaching it so just be prepared to take time out of your schedule to attend office hours or just study a lot on your own. Since physics 2 is a lot more conceptual than physics 1 it's harder to see the/imagine the relationships that you learn about in E&M, especially if you're a very visual leaner. If you ever feel like you're struggling my best recommendation is to find a TA or friend who knows this physics well and who you feel comfortable with so you can ask them all the questions you have and may think are stupid.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Jackson was one of the best parts of this course! He is a great teacher and is able to explain very difficult concepts in a way that is easy/more accessible to understand (I learned more through discussions/help room than I did in most lectures). He goes way beyond what's expected to provide additional practice problems each week to help us prepare for the exams and quizzes, and you can really tell he cares/wants everyone in the class to succeed. Personally I would have really struggled without him putting in so much effort to work out additional practice problems and hold help room each week, and we all really appreciate it!!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like that during lecture, the professor would write out the problem-solving process and talk us through which equations he would choose and why. Additionally, I like how succinct and relevant the lectures were.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Let it be known that the only reason I am writing this course evaluation is because Jackson Diodati is the best TA I have ever had and is the only reason I am passing this class. He went above and beyond in every way imaginable. He created problem sets with worked-out solutions for every week of content we had. He held office hours every week, and would hold extra review sessions if we asked for them. He was kind and patient and never made any of us feel stupid for not understanding what was going on, even if our questions were dumb. He was incredibly receptive to feedback as well. I genuinely would not have been successful in this class without him. If I could give him every award I could.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Though I found the information in this course interesting, I don't think it was tailored well for students pursuing the pre-health track. As someone who took the MCAT before taking physics 2, I feel that some of the work we were doing in class felt more so to prepare us to pursue physics as majors or careers that more heavily involve physics. I understand why a lot of pre-health students at Duke attempt to pursue physics outside of Duke, especially since this class can have a lot of information that may not be helpful for pre-health students. I do think that discussions on lens (especially the eyes) and MRI were very relevant. I hope that in the future, Duke can be more understanding of the physics needs of pre-health students to inspire more students to pursue physics at Duke.

response_text: This course is not too difficult, but you do need to spend time understanding the material. You can not waltz in off lectures alone and expect success.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course requires a lot of outside work in order to be successful. In particular, lecture alone is not enough to understand the material and how to problem solve in this course. Going to discussion and office hours help a LOT with understanding how to apply the material, and they are invaluable experiences in this class. I wouldn't recommend this course for a pre-health student, but you should take this course at Duke if you really like physics, biophysics, or any other major that requires a strong foundation in physics. This course is especially good for people who took AP Physics courses in high school because you will most likely do very well if that's the case. If you are pre-health without a strong foundation in physics, try to take this course elsewhere.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you don't have the credit for physics because you didn't take Physics C, but you did take AP Physics 1, then this course is unfortunately a required waste of time. There is so little "calculus" that this is essentially algebra-based AP Physics 1 with slightly harder problems. The midterms were literally easier than the AP Physics exams. This class should be able to be skipped with an AP Physics 1 credit, or at least be able to be replaced with a multivariable calculus physics class after a student has completed a multivar calc course. Truly a waste of time if a student has taken AP Physics 1, though that is not the fault of the instructor or TAs.Basically this should not be a hard requirement if a student hasn't taken Physics C in high school.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You need to have some knowledge about physics coming into the course (for example, how to draw free-body diagrams), and it is VERY assessment-heavy. The quizzes are worth twice as much as the labs, and you have a new quiz every week. Grading is tough (but reasonable) on assessments but not too bad for labs. Exams are long, and you have to really know the material going into them. If you aren't someone who can learn well from lectures, or if you have trouble concentrating during lectures, find alternative ways to learn the material early on. Don't count on the lectures as a way to learn all or most of the material (even if you are someone who learns well from lectures). Attend every discussion. Arya Roy is listed as one of the instructors, but he almost never lectures.If you have testing accommodations for extra time, know that they do not use the testing center, so if your extra time would cause your exam to extend into another class you'll have to make arrangements with your professor.

Also, make sure part a is correct if you use it to substitute it in for subsequent sections - I once missed a part a that resulted in missed points throughout 4 or 5 subsequent parts losing over 10 points when all I could not do was basic arithmetic.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a hard class, everyone does poorly. I suggest you try to go over lecture notes and the text book before class if you plan on going, as that is the only way to be able to slightly follow along. If you dont have time, dont go to lecture. Read the book, write down the equtions and key points, and try your best to do the hw without looking at the answers. Also try a few of the textbook problems prior to the hw, they are very different, btu can be a good introduction, so that you need the answers less when doing the hw. FInally, go to office hours, if you are lucky, you will find yourself with a group of people and a TA that actually wants to help you, and between the whole group you can get your questions clarified. Also join a sage group, I always found it a little less helpful bc I had it a while before the quiz so i hadnt started to look at the subject for the week yet, but it was still a huge help, and another good way for me to be introduced to the new subjects, since lecture was not doing it for me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You need to have some knowledge about physics coming into the course (for example, how to draw free-body diagrams), and it is VERY assessment-heavy. The quizzes are worth twice as much as the labs, and you have a new quiz every week. Grading is tough (but reasonable) on assessments but not too bad for labs. Exams are long, and you have to really know the material going into them. If you aren't someone who can learn well from lectures, or if you have trouble concentrating during lectures, find alternative ways to learn the material early on. Don't count on the lectures as a way to learn all or most of the material (even if you are someone who learns well from lectures). Attend every discussion. Arya Roy is listed as one of the instructors, but he almost never lectures.If you have testing accommodations for extra time, know that they do not use the testing center, so if your extra time would cause your exam to extend into another class you'll have to make arrangements with your professor.

response_text: In this class, I developed a strong foundation in understanding how objects move and interact under the influence of forces. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Phillip Barbeau created a supportive and engaging learning environment that matched the strong reviews I saw on Rate My Professor. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We had lecture twice a week with lots of theoretical explanation about that day's topics and a few quick practice problems. The drawings of scenarios were the most helpful thing from these lectures to help visualize what is happening. There was also be an (ungraded) homework to do every week regarding the topic discussed.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures would give us the knowledge we needed, and the homework/discussions were problems that applied that knowledge. I would keep this method of instruction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: While I think the professor was funny at times, he was very hard to follow, and did not help in my understanding of the subject. The less I went to class and more time I devoted to teaching myself the better I did in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Lecture was pretty erratic and often had me leaving more confused than when I walked in. It is clear Professor Barbeau is very passionate about physics and he does a good job teaching relevant information, but he often goes on conceptual and theoretical tangents that are largely extraneous and invite unnecessary confusion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of Physics 151L was supportive and engaging, which made a significant difference in my understanding of the material. The instructors explained concepts clearly and encouraged questions, creating a classroom atmosphere where it felt comfortable to seek help and explore ideas. The combination of lectures, problem-solving sessions, and labs provided a well-rounded approach that reinforced concepts from multiple angles. One component I found especially helpful was the structured problem sets, which pushed me to apply what I learned in class to new situations and think critically.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a hard class, everyone does poorly. I suggest you try to go over lecture notes and the text book before class if you plan on going, as that is the only way to be able to slightly follow along. If you dont have time, dont go to lecture. Read the book, write down the equtions and key points, and try your best to do the hw without looking at the answers. Also try a few of the textbook problems prior to the hw, they are very different, btu can be a good introduction, so that you need the answers less when doing the hw. FInally, go to office hours, if you are lucky, you will find yourself with a group of people and a TA that actually wants to help you, and between the whole group you can get your questions clarified. Also join a sage group, I always found it a little less helpful bc I had it a while before the quiz so i hadnt started to look at the subject for the week yet, but it was still a huge help, and another good way for me to be introduced to the new subjects, since lecture was not doing it for me.

response_text: If you're considering taking this course, I highly recommend it. It's a challenging yet rewarding course that provides a solid foundation in mechanics through a blend of theoretical learning and hands-on experimentation. The problem sets will push you to apply what you’ve learned in class, and you’ll really start to see how the concepts you study play out in the real world. Be prepared to think critically and problem-solve creatively, as the course encourages active learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion component of this class was by far the most helpful. I didn't get much out of lecture, but the homework problems and the discussions helped clarify things that were confusing, as well as give me plenty of opportunities to practice the concepts. My discussion instructor (Divine Kumah) was honestly a more effective lecturer than Dr. Barbeau.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to apply several of the concepts from lecture—motion, force, work and energy, momentum and collisions, rotation and torque, oscillations, and pressure—to a physical situation. During lab, we would start with a few theory questions and then move into collecting actual data/measurements, ultimately comparing our theoretical conclusions with our results. We learned how to conduct physics experiments, collect data, analyze graphs and measurements, and write up our results and conclusions as a group. Collaboration was definitely an important soft skill.

response_text: Connecting lecture material to a lab setting/ working under time and in group settings/ computer skills with new software.

response_text: How to conduct physics experiments, teamwork, and problem solving

response_text: Oscillations, springs, and friction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The lab TA answered our questions and usually had a solution if a problem arose. She was very well-equipped to guide us through the lab.
I appreciated that the lab concepts were directly related to something in lecture—it made our work feel relevant and productive. The experiments were fun, and the lab questions/write-ups encouraged us to think through how the systems we were dealing with worked. I also appreciated that the labs were a good length.

response_text: Isaac was very poor at time management, meaning we almost never got through all of the discussion questions, and were forced to start the quiz not having been through all of the questions, or we had to leave late sometimes in order to finish the questions and take the quiz. On top of his poor time management, he came in late pretty often, so that minimized our time even more. He spent too much time answering individual questiosn and not enough time going over the questions as a class, so most people got the short end of the stick. Also, in the beginning of the semester, he would have students come up to the board and write down the answers, which wasn't helpful because discussion's point is for a professional to teach it to me, not another student. I feel like it was unfair because some students in other discussions had really good TA's who were good at explaining and managing time, and they performed a lot better.

response_text: The discussion professor (Calvin Howell) would always go over the topics covered during that week in a more applicable manner than how it was covered in lecture, which was especially helpful. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Roy is a very engaging lecturer. He often gives real-world examples of the phenomena that we discuss and makes it a point of trying to explain complex mathematical ideas in a very intuitive way. He also takes time to connect different lectures and topics to each other so we are able to see the bigger picture and overarching narrative arc of the course as the weeks progress. Topics are presented in a very logical order where later topics build on earlier ones. I enjoyed Derek's demonstrations, which helped me visualize and connect abstract ideas to physical phenomena. We were provided a lot of resources, including homework sets and discussion problems that were helpful for me to process and practice key concepts and also familiarize myself with Professor Roy's problem-writing style, which was useful come exam time. I appreciated that there were lecture notes posted too, which basically allowed me to have two repeats of the same material to really understand it. In lecture, I could focus on picking up as much of the material as possible but rest assured that I could review the lecture notes to solidify/check my understanding afterwards.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved in my ability to manipulate equations, which involves using scaling, systems of equations, and backwards induction. I've gotten better at tying my intuition about physical concepts to check the way that I solve mathematical problems. I focus less on actual number values and more on the manipulation of physical constants/variables, and I always check that my units and vector direction make sense afterwards. I've also learned the importance of understanding the meaning behind equations and where they come from and how they scale with changes in variables, so I don't simply memorize equations anymore!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My fundamental physics abilities were greatly strengthened in this course as I now feel confident in my abilities to explain and derive many fascinating topics. I learned a great deal about sound, fluid mechanics, Maxwell's equations, optics, and circuits. Three specific things that I learned were: (1) how to derive the formula for power of a damped, driven oscillator and AC Circuits, as well as the close analogy between these two systems (2) An intuitive understanding of how the Maxwell Displacement current was derived, as well as the symmetry of Maxwell's equations (if magnetic monopoles are considered) and how these equations govern the properties of light (3) how sound travels, including the meaning of the decibel system.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is essential that you do your best to understand the content of the course conceptually, rather than simply memorizing formulas and trying to recall each word from the lecture. Take the time to review notes, lecture slides, the textbook (which is extremely thorough and helpful), and practice problems until you can re-derive formulas and understand the basic explanations for physical phenomenon. This extra effort will pay dividends in how much you enjoy the course and your overall learning.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A very important course for physics majors as a make-up for the frequently-botched E&M curriculum of AP Physics C, and a great NS choice for STEM majors (particularly math majors) seeking deeper understandings and applications of their fields. The instructor is a great personality, but can be inconsistent depending on the topic, partly due to the reliance on slides, which fits some topics much better than others. Great during the oscillators, wave mechanics, and Maxwell's Equations units; less so during the fluid mechanics and optics units. Overall, very beneficial course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: No curve, for level of difficulty think AP Physics C but you have to get 90% instead of 50% to get a 5/A

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Attendance is optional, but do not let that dissuade you from going to lectures. Not going to class puts you at a substantial disadvantage in comprehending the material -- there are given resources (slides, textbook) that can help you self-learn but they tend to be either a) not quite detailed enough or b) *too* detailed. The most efficient way to learn is by going to class. If lectures continue to be at 8:30 AM, be wary if you feel you will have a hard time waking up for them.

Assessments are difficult, but leniently graded with the understanding that students may perform worse on them than predicted by their level of understanding on any given day.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to use differential equations to solve important equations relevant to quantum mechanics such as Schrodinger's equation. I also learned about special relativity, which I did not know much about before, along with the consequences of relativity effects on experiments (such as Muon lifetime and decay). I also enjoyed learning the extra topics in the last weeks of class, especially concerning condensed matter physics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures were well paced, I liked that the instructor wrote/drew on the board as he lectured-- as a visual learner this was extremely helpful. The instructor was also very good about pausing for questions and had intuition for when the class might not understand completely, and he would accordingly say things in a different way, which was very helpful. This was the first physics class where I didn't feel reluctant to ask questions, because the instructor was very willing to re-explain, and as a result I felt very positively about the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I also enjoyed learning more about the experimental consequences of the theory that we learned in class, and especially liked the classes going into the stern-gerlach experiment. I also enjoyed the derivations of important equations completed in class, as it helped fill gaps in the textbooks where some derivation steps were skipped.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This has been my favorite physics class at Duke so far. The concepts are very stimulating, in particular it was fun to learn about relativity. The quantum mechanics part is difficult, but if you're a physics major, nothing out of the ordinary. The instructor is funny sometimes and stops often for questions, so lectures are enjoyable and extremely helpful to understand the materials. The lab is enjoyable too and relates well to the material. Overall, would recommend taking.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that the homework is difficult, but definitely doable if done in multiple passes. I would also highly recommend forming a study group to look over class material together, as there are very important nuances in material that can be reinforced through group studying. The lab reports also took a significantly longer time than the homework assignments, and should be given enough time (don't do lab reports last minute).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
I think my classmates set the expectations for this class high because they had a lot of prior knowledge (from high school competitions or research exposure? I don't know) that we never discussed in class. They are super fun people and I learned from them, but I also had to accept the fact that I performed below average. I doubted myself so many times this semester but I think I learned how to maintain a stable sense of self-worth. It was a very important takeaway. I just wish I didn't think I was alone because I was not alone. And neither are you, whoever is reading this. Life is not a competition with only one winner. That's boring. 
ASK QUESTIONS. Silently studying in your room can only take you so far. Go to office hours, raise your hand in class, politely speak up for yourself when you feel misunderstood. Don't be ashamed, don't be hard on yourself, don't feel bad for taking the professor's time, don't feel bad for taking your classmates' (your more experienced classmates who are asking deep, fundamental questions) time to go back to the basics. It's your learning opportunity as well as theirs. I wish I knew this sooner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course seriously made me grow as not only a physicist but a student. Starting with the former, up until this course, I never really thought to question the claims made within classical physics. This class took that perspective and walked through challenging it in the same way that it was done historically (first with optics, then special relativity, matter waves and ultimately with quantum mechanics. This made the difficult concepts approachable because the questions asked that led to their discovery were the next questions we asked in class - so even though the solutions were a little scary they were simply answers to things that didnt quite make sense. Connecting this all back, this class changed everything I thought I knew about physics - which was hard at times to deal with but made my appreciation and understanding for the subject as research targets it today (which is a whole world within itself I never dug into as I have never pushed beyond the curriculum previously). I feel like I learned A LOT about physics, and I also learned to push beyond what is presented.Further, as a student I feel as though I have grown as well. The concepts were pretty hard for me to grasp and things needed a little extra work to understand. I learned how to push through this discomfort and to not just nod at the steps but to understand why each just is made and why we make it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach classical mechanics from a Newtonian, Hamiltonian, and Lagrangian viewpoint. I also learned about the underlying math behind many of these concepts, such as canonical coordinates, Legendre transforms, and bivectors. Lastly, I learned about how classical mechanics forms a critical foundation for other physics fields such as E&M, quantum mechanics, and quantum computing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Cetina is an intriguing person, and probably one of the best scientists I've met in real life. His awkward enthusiasm is contagious.
But this class is so, extremely disorganized. Every other page on the lecture notes and homework consists of some typo, which, if you email Cetina, he would confirm promptly the correct version, but there are so, many, typos. He posts practice problems for exams but does not post solutions because he wants us to try working through problems independently, but in reality we're just collectively stuck and, unless you toil through every single office hour with Cetina to confirm your answers, you have little to no study material. He releases pre-class assignments at 12:30 noon and expects them to be completed at 4:40 pm the day of. Homework is tough but if you spend... I don't know, 40 hours? on them, you will improve and get good at mechanics. Exams are difficult, with 60-70% averages. He hasn't yet confirmed he would curve the grades.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course instructor was incredibly knowledgable and offered a high level of understanding towards many of the problems we encountered. Adiitonalyl, many of the problems given to us were interesting in scope and meaning. The homework and exams facilitated my learning in particular, because they all offered challenges that were just enough out of my reach to be possible, while offering maximal growth.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The general course structure of starting the week with a recitation and then having two lectures was very useful, both when using recitation to practice concepts taught in lecture the week before and using it to introduce the topic for the coming week. I also appreciated the many example problems and systems that were used during lecture to explain and practice lecture concepts, particularly when they had an accompanying demo in Mathematica showing the behavior of the system through a graph of some sort.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the written lecture notes, along with the slideshows. I felt that they were very useful to review after class was over. I also enjoyed the computational problem sets, though I would have liked more preparation and context before being given them. Lastly, I enjoyed the depth with which we went into seemingly simple systems, as it gave me a better feel and intuition for how to fully define a system and apply that reasoning to more complex problems later on.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Go to office hours. Don't be afraid to bug him. He loves talking about physics. And when he doesn't want to, he would say something. So as long as he doesn't say anything, throw him all your questions. Don't expect to do everything alone. Don't isolate yourself, and you don't deserve to be isolated. When he hosts minimal office hours for extremely difficult homework, please advocate for yourselves - he just temporarily forgets that we're learning all this for the first time. 
If you have questions left over from lecture/hw, deal with them as soon as possible, because if you don't, they will snowball into an impossible reading week. And it's so fulfilling to have no questions on previous material. 
You got this, I believe in you.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about thermal physics, particularly the micro-canonical ensemble, canonical ensemble, and grand canonical ensemble. The course followed Schroeder's textbook on thermal physics pretty closely, so all the material in there is what I learned. As for skills, I learned more about how to think about thermal systems as I had never taken a thermal course. We had to use many approximation techniques I had not encountered before, or forgot about, like expanding an exponential to the first few terms in the taylor expansion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned the formalism of the partition function, which is derived from first principles such as multiplicity. I also learned how to apply thermodynamic identities to different physical situations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a very difficult course, probably the most difficult physics course offered at Duke. The level of instruction is good and lectures are engaging with supplementary knowledge from a reliable textbook, but the amount of content being covered and the difficulty level of that content makes it very difficult to balance between reviewing for class, doing the homework, and studying enough to feel adequately prepared for exams. You will likely feel very lost for most of the class and not perform as well as you would like. Just push through, pay attention to lecture, read the text, and go to office hours.

course: PHYSICS-380-01 : INT TO QUANTUM INFORMATION SCI.PHYSICS-380-01.MATH-363-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Spend a lot of time reviewing the material outside of class for the exams, such as during weeks when there is no HW to work on. Exams are tough to do well on not because the questions are actually very difficult, but rather because the grading is unforgiving. For example, it is easy to lose more than half of the points on a question (more than 10% of your exam grade) if you make a simple computation error in part (a) and get deductions in further parts due to carry-through error. Some question parts with computation (that isn't just done within 1-2 steps) are also graded all or almost nothing. So if you want to do well you need to be able to do the questions very quickly and reserve plenty of time to double, triple, or ideally quadruple check all of your answers. Similarly, spend a lot of time on the HW such as with checking all your answers because the HW is 50% of your grade and like exams it can be easy to lose a lot of points.

response_text: This is a fine introduction to quantum information science for people with no background in quantum mechanics (or physics in general). You'll gain a good and relatively comprehensive understanding of the basics of quantum information science. The workload for the class is pretty light, but you'll still learn a decent amount from this course (especially if you're coming from a more mathematical background).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
In Physics 415/Biology 425, I developed a much deeper understanding of the intersection between physics and biology, especially the power of quantitative reasoning in biological systems. Three specific things I learned were:
- The Application of Physical Principles to Biological Systems: I learned how core physics concepts like force, energy, and entropy are applied to understand complex biological processes such as DNA packing, cell mechanics, and active matter.
- Exposure to Biophysical Research Techniques: The course introduced me to advanced experimental tools like super-resolution microscopy, atomic force microscopy, and electron microscopy, as well as how these tools are used to uncover biological mechanisms at the molecular and cellular scale.
- Critical Evaluation of Research: Through preparing and delivering a presentation on a cutting-edge biophysics research article, I gained valuable experience in critically analyzing scientific literature and effectively communicating complex ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Also looked into particle spin and perturbation theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read and use bra and ket notation. I understand how to work with Hermitian operators. I learned how to solve for the energy eigenstates of a state for various potentials, and why we want to solve for them. I became more familiar with thinking about quantum mechanical results probabilistically. I have learned how to mathematically explain various quantum phenomena such as tunneling and entanglement. I understand Pauli's exclusion principle! Also, perturbation theory has been (somewhat) demystified which is cool.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I developed the mathematical tools required to solve problems in quantum mechanics, such as bra & ket notation, expectation value, the Dirac-delta function, Hilbert space, and so much more. I also learned what people actually mean by the probabilistic nature of quantum after working with operators, eigenvalues, and eigenstates.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned how to apply the concepts learned in class to a variety of real world scenarios, such as quantum computing, NMR, and other topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Being introduced to the types of questions we could be asked, or at least the reasoning that goes behind figuring out how to set up a problem was helpful in developing my problem solving skills. On that note, as we are going over a concept, I found I learned a lot when we were asked to discuss in pairs/groups an answer to a question posed related to the lecture content. This was a good check for myself that I was paying attention, but also forced me to confront then and there where I was having difficulty and thus could ask questions. Also, the written and annotated homework solutions were very helpful.
