question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Office hours are not always helpful; Socolar isn't the best at understanding students' questions and providing relevant answers. But he's available and extremely kind. 
Feedback on homework is quite detailed and very helpful. 
I don't think I really understand quantum mechanics after this class - maybe that's the beauty of quantum, I don't know. But the class feels like a collection of isolated clusters of ideas and it's not always clear how everything is connected; I feel like I'm being dragged along by a list of key points instead of driven by questions, or gaps in previous knowledge, or the necessity of coming up with completely new ways of doing science. Maybe mentioning real-world applications more frequently, even if briefly, would help put things into perspective?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Some amount of collaboration is needed for this class. If you feel like you're out of place in the department of physics... I hear you, I was once in your shoes. I don't have easy solutions to share, sorry. We will reach our goals, but each of us will do so at our own pace. People I admire seldom take linear routes through academia; what are we if not reflections of those we look up to?
I made the same mistake (applying chain rule to derivatives) four times in the past six months! I learned to sanity-check my answers and make sure expectation values are not imaginary :D Would you say I'm stupid and not worthy of being a physicist? If not, then don't say that to yourself when you make mistakes, ask for help, or just generally have a bad day/week/month.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

That being said, be prepared to work hard and consistently. The content is cumulative so any gaps in your understanding early on will make it difficult to keep up.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

I would also recommend going to office hours regularly, as it was very helpful for better understanding what the homework problems are asking for and clearing any misconceptions or confusion regarding course content.

response_text: It definitely expanded my ideas of linear algebra, allowing me to think about these concepts more abstractly.I would spend a lot of time each week (10-15 hours) working on the homework outside of class and reading the book to understand concepts. However, in the last month the course got very abstract and much harder, and the abstraction made me feel like the course was veering into territory that was less relevant to my research interests. This made me stop submitting homework and then attend lecture far less often, and I then put much more effort into my other classes+interests.I don't know if there would've been a way to prevent me from dropping off in the last month; I don't think it makes sense to water down the content. I just wonder if maybe I wasn't the target audience for this class, and I realized it too late.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I only selected the above not because I found the course uninteresting or boring, but rather (and understandably so) the course gives an emphasis on the differential geometry aspects of the theory, and there is also some emphasis towards physics (in my opinion), which makes sense, given the crosslisting. However, my background is number theoretic, and while a lot of the theory here is absolutely important for my field, there are a lot of topics that I wished we had touched, even if it was just crumbs (Galois representations, representations over Q and fields of positive characteristic, group cohomology, Lie algebra cohomology, algebraic groups, etc). I know a lot of these are unreasonable for a first course, but I think I would be more than satisfiied if some acknowledgement to these was given. Or perhaps instead of a final exam, a final project or a final presentation would be more stimulating. I know I would feel a lot more excitement if I was writing something about these topics rather than worrying about the exam.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
(1) I learned how open-system dynamics can be non-Markovian because of information transfer between the system and the environment.
(2) I learned how the Lindblad master equation describes open-system dynamics under a set of simplifying assumptions.
(3) I learned how the concept of symmetries and conserved quantities, which are described by a single equivalent notion in closed dynamics, split apart into three inequivalent notions (strong symmetry, weak symmetry, conserved quantity) under open dynamics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: For one, the main instructor and TA were both amazing! They were very knowledgeable, and treated us all with the utmost respect. Anytime I had a question in the course, I was always given a direction to go by one of the instructors, and I never felt like it was a silly question or I was wasting their time, as is sometimes the case with instructors. For the size of the class and material covered, I felt like the structure of the course, with 50% interaction, 50% lecture worked excellently. I also 100% love and agree with the style of homework submissions which is no specific due date, and unlimited resubmissions. This style of submission, in my opinion, is the only proper way to do it, as the goal of problem sets should exclusively be to develop understanding of the material. Just to emphasize, I absolutely loved almost every aspect of this course. My background in quantum computing prior to the course was little to none, and I feel like this course did an excellent job at giving me a good base, as well as igniting my excitement for the field overall.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

On a relevant note, I particularly liked that there was no hard due dates for the problem sets. Taking away this pressure really helped me organize my thoughts, take meticulous notes, and set great fundamentals for me to explore quantum computing on my own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have developed a rigorous mathematical foundation and a new understanding for the formulation of quantum mechanics from postulates, how to describe relevant experiments detailing specific quantum phenomena and how we can somehow find a way to use the identity operator in almost every derivation. Having done McIntyre in my undergrad, which gave me a strong conceptual understanding, Sakurai challenged me to think more abstractly about the math behind quantum mechanics. A critical skill I picked up was being able to relate quantum mechanics to reality no mater how complicated the expressions we derived in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this was an excellent primer on quantum mechanics. Although I have taken undergraduate quantum mechanics and advanced quantum mechanics, these used the Griffiths book and had a different approach. We just calculated and rarely went into detail on why phenomenon occurred the way they did. In this course, I had a great overview of "why" in quantum mechanics and it was heartening to see that quantum mechanics can be taught in an exciting and engaging way while keeping the rigor up.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Development of operators from physical reasoning, i.e, "this operator is a 'thing' that acts on the system which produces this measurable effect, therefore it must look like this."
Manipulation of two level systems
Build up to Schrödinger's Eq.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Natalie is an excellent communicator of challenging ideas and is deeply attentive to her students and the questions they ask. It felt like an informal and welcoming environment, where we could freely clarify and ask questions or engage in class discussion. The instructor's flexibility with listening to individual students' personal goals for the class helped me to define what I wanted to get out of this class, a question that may not be asked by taking a core class where you can't negotiate with the curriculum. The open ended structure of the course is what was one of the strong points here, as I realise having an x number of topics to get through within a short time period may be unfeasible for a diverse class with different levels of preparation. Having no formal assignments actually encouraged me to put in more effort outside of class. There were days when I would not be in the mood to engage and others where I was more involved, and I enjoyed the freedom that was given to me as I had to focus on the core graduate classes close to exam times. The class flow was directly tailored to the students and it was challenging enough when I chose to engage with it, and often I did happily. I think it was critical to my first semester experience as a sort of safe space amidst the chaos of taking graduate classes and getting used to the setting of grad school. This felt like a class where I knew how much effort I would like to put in and see results in terms of my final self directed plan.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the way that learning objectives were handled and I think this class was vital for me. Going through the basics of quantum mechanics through basis representations and such was a new approach for me and made my mathematics in quantum much stronger. The instructor didn't baby us but gave us a good rundown of concepts and how to do the math related to every concept we learned which was a great approach. Too often, quantum classes just show math and struggle to develop a motivation or fall into pop science communication where the explanations are helpful and engaging but we aren't doing true physics because the math is scant or not there at all. This class is the absolute perfect incorporation of both rigorous mathematics we will need and also the appropriate engaging approach. The pace is fast but that is fine because we are expected to be learning things at our own pace in the background and there was always extra help from the instructor or TA to catch up. In class we often also went over things repeatedly which was a good mind exercise because quantum mechanics is not intuitive and repetition and tying back to past approaches constantly is good.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think Dr. Klco was able to adapt to the desires of the class, which ended up being an introduction to QM from a physical perspective. I am confident Dr. Klco would be able to meet any future groups where they are.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I would never have imagined that you could formulate quantum mechanics as an exciting trilogy of interconnected stories. But they were very entertaining and educational stories. The most stimulating part of the class was being able to engage with Natalie's stories and ask all the questions that inspired my curiosity.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because we approached class as an exploration and discussion and questioning was very encouraged. We had less of a lecture and more of a sit down with someone who led the charge. Obviously the instructor taught the lessons most of the time when students or the TA was not presenting, but I felt talked *to* instead of *at*. Real life experiments were often referenced by the instructor and TA rather than a more abstract approach and I personally loved how concrete that was. The not shying away from advanced topics (muon g-2, bloch sphere, stern gerlacht experiment, qubits, quantum circuit, neutrino oscillations, optics experiments, etc) and applications helped also emphasize that quantum mechanics is more fundamental than classical mechanics and we would often see examples of why and how. Math methods tie ins were frequent and appreciated. This was taught with a physical reference, by physicists who have expertise in the mathematics. It was not a vague math course that sets the tone for some physics. That is the way all quantum mechanics should be taught and I thrived this way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The most valuable things I have learned are
1) Understanding the importance of choosing coordinates and becoming familiar with the techniques used to choose the most informative ones
2) A fairly deep knowledge of the numerous approaches to the theory of classical mechanics and how it all boils down to the Principal of Least Action
3) A new and deeper confidence in my physics toolset to tackle the upcoming rigors of graduate school courses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Needless to say, this was a challenging class for my first grad level class. Main things covered were fluid mechanics, chaos theory, action angle variables, first order perturbations, hamilton jacobi frmaework, hamiltonian, rigid body motion, oscillations and normal modes, lagrangian mechanics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do yourself a favour and save yourself buckets of tears by never opening Goldstein. Especially if you don't have a dual degree in math or have not taken an advanced classical mechanics class before. Look to alternative sources of information like Landau or Taylor or online lecture notes. I found that MIT Open Courseware's Classical Mechanics 3 allowed me to complete all homework problems and succeed in this class. Compare reading a 100 page chapter in Goldstein on symplectic notation to 5 pages of lecture notes just to attempt the first homework problem. This is not an intuitive class so be prepared to feel frustrated.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. SYMMETRIES!! I learned a lot about how to come at problems with symmetries in mind to simplify them first, which is obviously a very good skill to know as a physicist
2. The parallels between electrostatics and magnetostatics (and where the parallels fail). I think this was a particularly interesting part of the course. Using knowledge gained in electrostatics to solve some magnetostatics problem (or at least the insight from previous problems) was very enlightening. 
3. I developed my skills in math a lot in this course. Specifically, in solving Laplace's equation, using spherical harmonics/Legendre polynomials, vector calculus, etc as well as gaining some mathematical insight. I still have a long way to go, but this course was fantastic in teaching those skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciate maintaining a set office hours time. I appreciate the professor's willingness to meet outside class time and even outside normal office hours time if necessary for students, especially around exams.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor's lectures were good and it was nice that he provided his lecture notes, which were of high quality. However, I would not keep even these things as is for future years. What I would keep is Professor Chandrasekharan, he is a great teacher and cares about his students. The HWs were fantastic. The selection of problems from Zangwill were well chosen and the written problems were typically good as well. I feel like i learned a lot from doing the HWs. Some people complained about the HW being too hard or too long, but I don't agree. We had 6 problems per week, with some weeks off around the exams. The work was hard, but reasonable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Shailesh Chandrasekharan was one of the best professors I have ever had. He is fantastic at explaining concepts and problems. He has so much insight into problems that it is helpful to even just chat with him about problems without doing them explicitly. Not only was he great at explaining electrodynamics concepts, but he drew parallels between EM and quantum mechanics or explained how quantum mechanical effects explained some things in EM -- this was a fantastic addition to the course, as it made it more interesting and helped for learning QM.But my favorite thing about Professor Chandrasekharan is that he made me feel intelligent, even when others would say the mistake/misunderstanding I had was "stupid" or silly. Anytime I asked a simple question, he never made it seem like I should already know the answer -- he always took the same time and effort answering even basic questions. I did not do too well on the first midterm exam and when I met with him to discuss it and was worried about passing the class, he reassured me that I would still be able to pass AND that the mistakes/misunderstandings I had were not abnormal and quite common for first year physics PhDs, including himself when he was first learning EM. I think that meeting with him actually changed my entire perception of graduate school. He made me more confident in myself and reignited my passion for learning anything and everything physics-related.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked how the class was structured. I am not personally a fan of the flipped classroom style of teaching; in every class I've been in that has used this method, I always felt I left with a lesser understanding of the material (I mention this b/c I was asked to talk about the flipped classroom in an email). There was a lot I liked about this class; so, I'm going to break down the things I did like.The lectures were really good. It was clear that Dr. Chandrasekharan (I'll just refer to him as Dr. C from now on) put a great amount of time into learning the material before the lectures so he could answer questions we had confidently. I understand this is not the normal class he teaches; however, it did not feel as such. I thought the lectures and their notes had the important points from the book down and were a great reference to look on during the lectures themselves. I also really liked the examples done in the lecture notes.The homeworks were also very well thought out. Their difficulty was, for the most part, good. I felt that they challenged me to think on the material and ensured I understood the methods described in class. I did like how for the problems that were longer and more challenging there were hints that guided us through.The office hours for the class were also very helpful. Every time I went I knew that I would leave with my question answered and a greater understanding of the course material. If I had a question on a homework problem, Dr. C wouldn't just give us the answers to the problem, but would help work it out with us so that we understood the entire process. I remember there was one office hours that about 15 people showed up to ask questions. That's the sign of a good professor.The last thing I will touch on is how I felt comfortable asking questions in Dr. C's class and office hours. I knew that if I asked a question I wouldn't be talked down to as if my question was stupid, but rather the complete opposite. He would encourage the question and touch on why it was important to understand the material. I remember one day in his office hours me and a few other students were asking about a problem dealing with free current. While discussing our misunderstanding of the question, he noticed that we were approaching the problem the wrong way. He then mentioned the problem was tricky for him as well and that even he had attempted to do the same thing we did at first. Even though it was a small comment, it stuck with me as it made him feel (I know this is going to sound weird), but human. I feel like many professors I've had in the past are quick to put up this persona of being incapable of being wrong, and that always felt intimidating. However, that one comment from Dr. C made me feel the complete opposite.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the homework sets were extremely helpful, as were the office hours.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
These were the best physics lectures I have ever had. I know Shailesh spent many hours preparing them and having the notes available to us in advance - thank you!!! 
I do think that the lecture notes could have been a bit more detailed, especially in terms of explaining worked examples. The examples in Zangwill typically are not easy and involve references to many previous examples, and are "worked" in the text without showing many of the key steps. I think I could have avoided a lot of confusion by using class time to explain the detail of examples - if we want to gloss over how the problem is solved, we can just read the book.
I also wish the lectures did a bit more to discuss methods of problem solving - there is almost always a simple algorithm to go through solving problems (even though the calculations are involved - can't avoid that) that you have to figure out by truly "digesting" the material. But, it is usually very hard to "digest" the material and come away with the most important and practical points simply by reading the textbook. Lectures can help with this immensely! As a key example: Zangwill chapter 4. The actual concepts are quite simple, and their implementation is as well. But it was very convoluted in Zangwill.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think that anyone who is a good test-taker is fine. This seems to be the only student quality that matters. But the course is virtually only exams. Homework was 20% of the grade and 80% was exams. The average grade on the first midterm was essentially a 50%. While I understand this is graduate physics and grades are often 'curved' later (how exactly final grades get determined numerically in these graduate physics classes remains a mystery to me), I find it really disappointing that this is considered acceptable. Normally, a class average like this is a reflection of the teacher. I want to make it very clear that qualities like improving over the course of the semester, being proactive and communicative in your studies, and engaging outside of class are absolutely not taken into consideration when grading. You will be graded exclusively by how you compare numerically to the rest of the class. I also want to point out that when studying for any major exam (MCAT, LSAT, SAT, GRE, etc.) the main study method is practice exams, including students studying to take the qualifiers in the Duke Physics Dept. before they were removed. If courses are currently intended to be stricter and harsher to compensate for removing the qualifiers, then they should at least be held to the same test-taking standards. Shailesh denied providing any guidance or previous/practice exams for studying when asked. We were given a set of lectures with ambiguous start/end points to study from that encapsulated a triple digit number of pages in the textbook and nothing else. Even the formula sheets we were allowed to make were useless when trying to predict what the exam would be about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Chandrasekharan facilitated a very interactive, professional, learning-oriented classroom environment. For one thing, I really appreciated his organized lecture notes that he posted ahead of class time and which he worked through during class. This made it easy to follow his lectures and review them afterward. He is an excellent teacher and goes out of his way to explain concepts clearly and in depth. He not only teaches "how" to solve a problem, but also how to think and understand what we're doing and make connections across course content. He is happy to answer questions in and out of class and I found his office hours exceedingly helpful to facilitate my learning. He even went out of his way to have review sessions for the midterm and final exams. For the homeworks, I appreciated the format where one problem was graded more heavily than the others - this took some pressure of homework grades and allowed me to do the work more for the intrinsic learning opportunity. Also, shoutout to Govind our TA who was awesome! He was exceedingly helpful in TA help room hours and also in leading several of the class sessions.

To study for the exam, you needed to pay close attention to the content covered on the practice exam. Overall, the different pieces of the course - lecture, homework, reading, exam - felt very fragmented and disconnected.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The most stimulating part for me is to learn a spirit from Professor Liu. As Professor Liu always says "nothing fancy", "no more than 2-spin system", "no more than Harmonic Oscillator". Such saying sounds funny, but actually pass me a question with answer, which is "Are we able to learn all the materials of QM?", "NO!". So, how to learn QM or anything else? I believe Professor Liu gave a good answer, which is to grasp the idea and origin, understand several examples and most importantly, to figure out what is a math highly involved problem but already solved (like special functions) and what is a scientific research problem (like a Hamiltonian hard to solve). I learned that we can never learn everything for any subject or topic, but it is not a shame, it is normal. The importance is to seek the basis thing and to appreciate the whole picture. So, I learned that I should not be afraid of anything looks "fancy", just to learn and to ask question. In this sense, Professor Liu teaches me such spirit and render me to be confident to face anything looks fancy in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course deepened my understanding of the position of quantum mechanics in modern physics research. Specific things that were developed were practical application of many body Hamiltonians through numerical homeworks, motivation and development of quantum field theory for relativistic particles, and the use of the Fock space formalism to study spin systems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I learned about paradigm shift in terms of how to think about Quantum Mechanics of varying number of particles which is easily realized using the formalism of Fock space. I learned about how Fock space naturally accounts for, in the case of identical particles, the bosonic and Fermionic symmetric and antisymmtric wavefunctions and how Pauli's exclusion principle is an emergent property of this. I also learned about symmetry transformations and quantization of the electromagnetism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Fock space representation for many-body quantum physics. This was the core of the course and I think I learned a great deal about annihilation/creation operators and operators in fock space, as well as transformations to different bases.
2. I learned a lot about computational approaches for certain models in physics. My coding skills improved a lot.
3. The differences between bosonic and fermionic systems and how it arises from the commutation relations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) learned to think in terms of Fock spaces, and work with the new formalism.
2) Homework helped with developing a working knowledge.
3) Prepared for a field theory class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned primarily about lattice approaches to quantum mechanics. This naturally leads to many body quantum mechanics and eventually fields. I've primarily been exposed to perturbative methods, so lattice physics is quite new to me. It helped me appreciate the properties of the kinds of infinities that arise is continuum mechanics. I also learned to appreciate better the types of symmetries and implementations that are common to physics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was a gentle (smooth, not easy) transition from single-particle quantum mechanics to introductory field theory. It’s the best physics class I've ever taken. I really appreciate the professor's attention to detail and the many hours that he spent designing the course and preparing the lectures. Thank you!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I’ve learned many exciting things, including the application of regularization in quantum mechanics, the formalism of Fock Space for many-body systems, and how to apply these concepts using numerical techniques like quantum Monte Carlo to solve practical problems.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that providing lecture notes after lecture was very useful for reference both in the immediate with regards to homework and with respect to the future. I think that homework that focuses more on developing interesting results and derivations is also helpful not only for reinforcing what was learned in class, but because they make the process of practicing and working with the material more enjoyable. Of course, Dr. Chandrasekharan is a very competent teacher. He is very good at explaining the material and resolving confusion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My favorite course component was the integration between the lectures and the homework exercises. Unlike in other courses, the homework was designed by the professor to be directly related to the lecture content and really served to deepen and enhance our understanding of the course content by having us revisit the details of the calculations on our own time. I feel like the hours I spent on homework were so beneficial because I didn’t have to spend nearly as much time feeling "stuck" as I tried to interpret the questions or puzzle out when a textbook author could possibly be looking for in a solution. In addition to filling in details, the homework also guided us to develop a computational toolbox for solving QM problems, which I think was very helpful.

I do think it might be easier to get higher engagement if the class is at a more normal time. Personally, I think that professors should be willing to take an hour and half out of one day per year in order to advertise their research and recruit new graduate students, especially with how important a graduate student can be for research.

I personally found the course fascinating and it gave me a good overview of our department. But the payoff there doesn't require the timing; it is a large investment to plan the weekly schedule in such a way to make considerations for this course but also spend long hours on other vital things. That being said, I think all students should have a familiarity with what is being done at Duke in Physics so I have no issue with mandatory attendance. It is stimulating to hear about different professors and can spur interdisciplinary research and kick off ideas. That is the most stimulating aspect of the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I only realized when it was too late to drop/add, that this course is in the best interest of non-physics students. Roughly half of the class is in STEM, while the other half is in economics. In terms of taking a cool, effortless course that knocks off an NS code, this seminar is the best of the best and very ideal. The only "workload" is literally going to and back from DQC. For me as a physical sciences student, I have only regrets. How I wish I audited this course. On the bright side, I am happy that I could visit DQC twice a week and meet several like-minded peers. On the other hand, I wasted one full credit this semester that could have been allocated to a real physics course like PHYS 163. Please do note that in the future, PHYS 89S may have a different topic and different instructor. Prof. Monroe is a great guy and delivers lighthearted lectures with a good (and occasionally dark) sense of humor, but could come in unprepared and make mistakes during lectures.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about space and physics in this course. Professor Walter did a very good job of going over rather complicated ideas in easy to understand ways and was very good about answering our questions. I also learned how to go through a decent amount of readings and summarize them in an efficient manner. In addition, I learned how to calculate the Hubble constant from supernova data, which is fun.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about Hubble constant and the universe's rate of expansion and how it has allowed us to calculate the Universe's age.
I learned about general and special relativity and how time is not absolute but connected to space.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's more work that you'd expect, particularly to get high grades on assignments, but the material is intellectually stimulating. Don't fret about the final project, it's fun and spread out over many weeks.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure to do the readings and start them right after they are assigned, that way you don't rush on the last day or two of when it's due (I avoided that, but many other students fell into that trap). Also, front load the work for your final presentation, it will come faster than you think. Finally, I recommend doing the specific presentation during the semester earlier rather than later--you'll have more time because earlier in the semester is easier academically overall.
